Aliprantis
CHAPTER 3

THE THEORY OF MEASURE

At the turn of the nineteenth century it was quite apparent to mathematicians that the properties of continuous functions and Riemann’s theory of integration were not rich enough to solve many scientific problems. The inadequacies of the continuous functions led them to search for different classes of functions that would provide solutions to a variety of problems.

Around the beginning of the twentieth century, the theory of measure was originated. At that time, it was realized that to get a better understanding of the structure of functions it was necessary to make a thorough study of the subsets of Euclidean spaces. To study these sets, it became clear that the classical notions of length, area, and volume needed to be generalized. The search for devising ways of assigning a concept of a “measure” to a given set of points has its roots in that period.

E. Borel [4] in 1898 was the first to establish a measure theory on the subsets of the real numbers known today as Borel sets. Soon after (in 1902), H. Lebesgue [21] presented his pioneering work on Lebesgue measure, and a little later (around 1918), C. Carathéodory introduced and studied the properties of outer measures. From then on a rapid development of the theory of measure, which included among its contributors the most prominent mathematicians of the first half of the twentieth century, followed.

This chapter discusses in detail the theory of measure. We start our study by introducing the concept of a semiring of sets and then proceed by studying the properties of measures on semirings. The important notion of the outer measure is introduced and studied next. It is followed by a detailed investigation of the measurable sets and measurable functions. Our attention is then turned to the properties of simple and step functions and to the basic properties of the Lebesgue measure. The chapter culminates with an investigation of convergence in measure and a discussion on abstract measurability properties.

12. SEMIRINGS AND ALGEBRAS OF SETS

In this section the notion of a semiring of sets is introduced and its properties are studied. A semiring of sets is the simplest family of sets for which a measure theory can be built. It turns out that most “reasonable” collections of sets satisfy the semiring properties.

Definition 12.1. Let XXX be a nonempty set. A collection SSS of subsets of XXX is called a semiring if it satisfies the following properties:

  1. The empty set belongs to SSS; that is ∅∈S\emptyset \in S∅∈S.
  2. If A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S; then A∩B∈SA \cap B \in SA∩B∈S; that is, SSS is closed under finite intersections.
  3. The set difference of any two sets of SSS can be written as a finite union of pairwise disjoint members of SSS. That is, for every A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S; there exist C1,…,CnC_1, \ldots, C_nC1​,…,Cn​ in SSS (depending on AAA and BBB) such that
    A∖B=⋃i=1nCiandCi∩Cj=∅ if i≠j.A \setminus B = \bigcup_{i=1}^n C_i \quad \text{and} \quad C_i \cap C_j = \emptyset \text{ if } i \ne j.A∖B=i=1⋃n​Ci​andCi​∩Cj​=∅ if i=j.

Now, let S\mathcal{S}S be a semiring of subsets of XXX. A subset AAA of XXX is called a σ\sigmaσ-set with respect to S\mathcal{S}S (or simply a σ\sigmaσ-set) if there exists a disjoint sequence {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S (i.e., An∩Am=∅A_n \cap A_m = \emptysetAn​∩Am​=∅ if n≠mn \neq mn=m) such that
A=⋃n=1∞An.A = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n.A=n=1⋃∞​An​.
If
A=⋃i=1nAiA = \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} A_iA=i=1⋃n​Ai​
with A1,…,An∈SA_1, \dots, A_n \in \mathcal{S}A1​,…,An​∈S and Ai∩Aj=∅A_i \cap A_j = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅ for i≠ji \neq ji=j, then AAA is a σ\sigmaσ-set.
To see this, put Ai=∅A_i = \emptysetAi​=∅ for i>ni > ni>n. It follows from Definition 12.1 that A∖BA \setminus BA∖B is a σ\sigmaσ-set for every pair AAA and BBB in S\mathcal{S}S.

Some basic properties of σ\sigmaσ-sets are included in the next theorem.

Theorem 12.2. For a semiring SSS, the following statements hold:

  1. If A∈SA \in SA∈S and A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S, then A∖⋃i=1nAiA \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_iA∖⋃i=1n​Ai​ can be written as a finite union of disjoint sets of SSS (and hence, it is a σ\sigmaσ-set).
  2. For every sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of SSS, the set A=⋃n=1∞AnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA=⋃n=1∞​An​ is a σ\sigmaσ-set.
  3. Countable unions and finite intersections of σ\sigmaσ-sets are σ\sigmaσ-sets.
Proof

Proof.

(1) We use induction on nnn. For n=1n = 1n=1, the statement is true from the definition of the semiring.
Now, assume the statement is true for some nnn. Let A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S, and let A1,…,An,An+1∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n, A_{n+1} \in \mathcal{S}A1​,…,An​,An+1​∈S. By the induction hypothesis, there exist B1,…,Bk∈SB_1, \ldots, B_k \in \mathcal{S}B1​,…,Bk​∈S such that
B=A∖⋃i=1nAi=⋃i=1kBiandBi∩Bj=∅ if i≠j.B = A \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i = \bigcup_{i=1}^k B_i \quad \text{and} \quad B_i \cap B_j = \emptyset \text{ if } i \ne j.B=A∖i=1⋃n​Ai​=i=1⋃k​Bi​andBi​∩Bj​=∅ if i=j.
Consequently,
A∖⋃i=1n+1Ai=B∖An+1=⋃i=1k(Bi∖An+1).A \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} A_i = B \setminus A_{n+1} = \bigcup_{i=1}^k (B_i \setminus A_{n+1}).A∖i=1⋃n+1​Ai​=B∖An+1​=i=1⋃k​(Bi​∖An+1​).
By property (3) of Definition 12.1, each Bi∖An+1B_i \setminus A_{n+1}Bi​∖An+1​ can be written as a finite union of disjoint sets of S\mathcal{S}S.
Since Bi∩Bj=∅B_i \cap B_j = \emptysetBi​∩Bj​=∅ if i≠ji \ne ji=j, it easily follows that
A∖⋃i=1n+1AiA \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} A_iA∖i=1⋃n+1​Ai​
can be written as a finite union of disjoint sets of S\mathcal{S}S.
This completes the induction and the proof of (1).

(2) Let {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S. Put
A=⋃n=1∞An,A = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n,A=n=1⋃∞​An​,
and then write
A=⋃n=1∞BnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_nA=n=1⋃∞​Bn​
with
B1=A1andBn+1=An+1∖⋃i=1nAifor n≥1.B_1 = A_1 \quad \text{and} \quad B_{n+1} = A_{n+1} \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} A_i \quad \text{for } n \geq 1.B1​=A1​andBn+1​=An+1​∖i=1⋃n​Ai​for n≥1.
Observe that Bi∩Bj=∅B_i \cap B_j = \emptysetBi​∩Bj​=∅ if i≠ji \ne ji=j, and by statement (1), each BiB_iBi​ is a σ\sigmaσ-set.
It now follows easily that AAA is itself a σ\sigmaσ-set.

(3) The proof follows from (2), and property (2) of Definition 12.1. ■\blacksquare■

The proof of part (2) of the preceding theorem also guarantees the validity of the following useful result:

Lemma 12.3. If {An}\{A_n\}{An​} is a sequence of sets in a semiring SSS, then there exists a disjoint sequence {Cn}\{C_n\}{Cn​} of SSS such that
⋃n=1∞An=⋃n=1∞Cn\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty C_nn=1⋃∞​An​=n=1⋃∞​Cn​
and for each nnn there exists some kkk with Cn⊆AkC_n \subseteq A_kCn​⊆Ak​.

Some natural collections of sets happen to satisfy other properties that are stronger than those of a semiring. The “algebra of sets” is such a collection, and its definition follows.

Definition 12.4. A nonempty collection SSS of subsets of a set XXX which is closed under finite intersections and complementation is called an algebra of sets (or simply an algebra). That is, SSS is an algebra whenever it satisfies the following properties:
i. If A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S, then A∩B∈SA \cap B \in SA∩B∈S.
ii. If A∈SA \in SA∈S, then Ac∈SA^c \in SAc∈S.

Three basic properties of an algebra are included in the next theorem.

Theorem 12.5. For an algebra of sets SSS, the following statements hold:

  1. ∅,X∈S\emptyset, X \in S∅,X∈S.
  2. The algebra SSS is closed under finite unions and intersections.
  3. The algebra SSS is a semiring.
Proof

(1) Since S\mathcal{S}S is nonempty, there exists some A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S. Now, by hypothesis Ac∈SA^c \in \mathcal{S}Ac∈S, and so,
∅=A∩Ac∈S.\emptyset = A \cap A^c \in \mathcal{S}.∅=A∩Ac∈S.
Moreover,
X=∅c∈S.X = \emptyset^c \in \mathcal{S}.X=∅c∈S.

(2) Let A,B∈SA, B \in \mathcal{S}A,B∈S. Then
A∪B=(Ac∩Bc)c∈S,A \cup B = (A^c \cap B^c)^c \in \mathcal{S},A∪B=(Ac∩Bc)c∈S,
and the rest of the proof can be completed easily by induction.

(3) We have to verify only property (3) of Definition 12.1. But this is obvious in view of the identity
A∖B=A∩Bc.■A \setminus B = A \cap B^c.\blacksquareA∖B=A∩Bc.■

We continue by illustrating the notions of semiring and algebra of sets with examples.

Example 12.6. For every nonempty set XXX, the collection S={∅,X}S = \{\emptyset, X\}S={∅,X} is an algebra of sets. This is the “smallest” (with respect to inclusion) possible algebra.■\blacksquare■

Example 12.7. For every nonempty set XXX, its power set P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) (i.e., the collection of all subsets of XXX) forms an algebra. This is the “largest” possible algebra.■\blacksquare■

Example 12.8. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a nonempty pairwise disjoint family of subsets of a set XXX. Then S=F∪{∅}S = \mathcal{F} \cup \{\emptyset\}S=F∪{∅} is a semiring of subsets of XXX. To see this, note first that ∅∈S\emptyset \in S∅∈S. Now, if A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S, then A∩BA \cap BA∩B is either empty or equal to AAA. Likewise, A∖BA \setminus BA∖B is either empty or equal to AAA. Thus, A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S implies that A∩BA \cap BA∩B and A∖BA \setminus BA∖B both belong to SSS, and so SSS is a semiring.■\blacksquare■

Example 12.9. If a,b∈Ra, b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R, let us write [a,b)=∅[a, b) = \emptyset[a,b)=∅ if a≥ba \geq ba≥b and (as usual) [a,b)={x∈R:a≤x<b}[a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a \le x < b\}[a,b)={x∈R:a≤x<b} if a<ba < ba<b. Then the collection
S={[a,b):a,b∈R}S = \{ [a, b) : a, b \in \mathbb{R} \}S={[a,b):a,b∈R}
is a semiring of subsets of R\mathbb{R}R, which is not an algebra (for instance, notice that [0,1)∪[2,3)∉S[0, 1) \cup [2, 3) \notin S[0,1)∪[2,3)∈/S).■\blacksquare■

Example 12.10. Let SSS denote the collection of all subsets AAA of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn for which there exist intervals [a1,b1),…,[an,bn)[a_1, b_1), \ldots, [a_n, b_n)[a1​,b1​),…,[an​,bn​) such that
A=[a1,b1)×⋯×[an,bn).A = [a_1, b_1) \times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n).A=[a1​,b1​)×⋯×[an​,bn​).
(If ai≥bia_i \geq b_iai​≥bi​ holds for some iii, then [ai,bi)=∅[a_i, b_i) = \emptyset[ai​,bi​)=∅, and so A=∅A = \emptysetA=∅.) Then SSS is a semiring of subsets of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn. To see this, note first that only the third property of the semiring definition needs verification; the other two are trivial. The proof is based upon the following identity among sets A,B,C,A, B, C,A,B,C, and DDD:
A×B∖C×D=[(A∖C)×B]∪[(A∩C)×(B∖D)],(★)A \times B \setminus C \times D = [(A \setminus C) \times B] \cup [(A \cap C) \times (B \setminus D)], \tag{★}A×B∖C×D=[(A∖C)×B]∪[(A∩C)×(B∖D)],(★)
where the sets of the union on the right-hand side are disjoint.

For the proof, use induction on nnn. For n=1n = 1n=1 the result is straightforward. Assume it now true for some nnn. We have to show that any set of the form
[a1,b1)×⋯×[an,bn)×[an+1,bn+1)∖[c1,d1)×⋯×[cn,dn)×[cn+1,dn+1)[a_1, b_1) \times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n) \times [a_{n+1}, b_{n+1}) \setminus [c_1, d_1) \times \cdots \times [c_n, d_n) \times [c_{n+1}, d_{n+1})[a1​,b1​)×⋯×[an​,bn​)×[an+1​,bn+1​)∖[c1​,d1​)×⋯×[cn​,dn​)×[cn+1​,dn+1​)
can be written as a finite union of disjoint sets from the (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-dimensional collection SSS.
But this can be easily shown by letting
A=[a1,b1)×⋯×[an,bn),B=[an+1,bn+1),A = [a_1, b_1) \times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n), \quad B = [a_{n+1}, b_{n+1}),A=[a1​,b1​)×⋯×[an​,bn​),B=[an+1​,bn+1​),
C=[c1,d1)×⋯×[cn,dn),D=[cn+1,dn+1)C = [c_1, d_1) \times \cdots \times [c_n, d_n), \quad D = [c_{n+1}, d_{n+1})C=[c1​,d1​)×⋯×[cn​,dn​),D=[cn+1​,dn+1​)
in (★)\text{(★)}(★) and using the induction hypothesis.■\blacksquare■

An intermediate notion between semirings and algebras is that of a ring of sets. A ring of sets (or simply a ring) is a nonempty collection of subsets R\mathcal{R}R of a set XXX satisfying these properties:
a. If A,B∈RA, B \in \mathcal{R}A,B∈R, then A∪B∈RA \cup B \in \mathcal{R}A∪B∈R.
b. If A,B∈RA, B \in \mathcal{R}A,B∈R, then A∖B∈RA \setminus B \in \mathcal{R}A∖B∈R.

Every ring R\mathcal{R}R contains the empty set. Indeed, since R\mathcal{R}R is nonempty, there exists A∈RA \in \mathcal{R}A∈R, and so ∅=A∖A∈R\emptyset = A \setminus A \in \mathcal{R}∅=A∖A∈R. Clearly, every algebra of sets is a ring of sets. Also, a ring R\mathcal{R}R is necessarily a semiring. Indeed, if A,B∈RA, B \in \mathcal{R}A,B∈R, then the relation A∩B=A∖(A∖B)A \cap B = A \setminus (A \setminus B)A∩B=A∖(A∖B) shows that A∩B∈RA \cap B \in \mathcal{R}A∩B∈R.
Another useful concept is that of a σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets.

Definition 12.11. An algebra S\mathcal{S}S of subsets of some set XXX is called a σ\sigmaσ-algebra if every union of a countable collection of members of S\mathcal{S}S is again in S\mathcal{S}S. That is, in addition to S\mathcal{S}S being an algebra, ⋃n=1∞An\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n⋃n=1∞​An​ belongs to S\mathcal{S}S for every sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of S\mathcal{S}S.

By virtue of ⋂n=1∞An=(⋃n=1∞Anc)c\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n = \left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^c \right)^c⋂n=1∞​An​=(⋃n=1∞​Anc​)c, it easily follows that every σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets is also closed under countable intersections.

Every collection of subsets F\mathcal{F}F of a nonempty set XXX is contained in a smallest σ\sigmaσ-algebra (with respect to the inclusion relation). This σ\sigmaσ-algebra is the intersection of all σ\sigmaσ-algebras that contain F\mathcal{F}F (notice that P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) is one of them), and is called the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by F\mathcal{F}F.

An important σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets is the σ\sigmaσ-algebra of all Borel sets of a topological space. Its definition is given next.

Definition 12.12. The Borel sets of a topological space (X,τ)(X, \tau)(X,τ) are the members of the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the open sets. The σ\sigmaσ-algebra of all Borel sets of (X,τ)(X, \tau)(X,τ) will be denoted by B\mathcal{B}B.

EXERCISES
  1. If XXX is a topological space, then show that the collection
    S={C∩O:C closed and O open}={C1∖C2:C1,C2 closed sets}S = \{ C \cap O : C \text{ closed and } O \text{ open} \} = \{ C_1 \setminus C_2 : C_1, C_2 \text{ closed sets} \}S={C∩O:C closed and O open}={C1​∖C2​:C1​,C2​ closed sets}
    is a semiring of subsets of XXX.
Solution.

From ∅=∅∩∅\emptyset = \emptyset \cap \emptyset∅=∅∩∅ and X=X∩XX = X \cap XX=X∩X, we see that ∅,X∈S\emptyset, X \in \mathcal{S}∅,X∈S. Next, notice that C1∩O1, C2∩O2∈SC_1 \cap O_1,\, C_2 \cap O_2 \in \mathcal{S}C1​∩O1​,C2​∩O2​∈S imply
(C1∩O1)∩(C2∩O2)=(C1∩C2)∩(O1∩O2)∈S.(C_1 \cap O_1) \cap (C_2 \cap O_2) = (C_1 \cap C_2) \cap (O_1 \cap O_2) \in \mathcal{S}.(C1​∩O1​)∩(C2​∩O2​)=(C1​∩C2​)∩(O1​∩O2​)∈S.

Now, if C1∩O1, C2∩O2∈SC_1 \cap O_1,\, C_2 \cap O_2 \in \mathcal{S}C1​∩O1​,C2​∩O2​∈S, then
C1∩O1∖C2∩O2=(C1∩O1)∩(C2∩O2)c=(C1∩O1)∩(C2c∪O2c)=(C1∩O1)∩[C2c∪(O2c∩C2)]=[C1∩(O1∩C2c)]∪[(C1∩C2∩O2c)∩O1]=A∪B,\begin{aligned} C_1 \cap O_1 \setminus C_2 \cap O_2 &= (C_1 \cap O_1) \cap (C_2 \cap O_2)^c \\ &= (C_1 \cap O_1) \cap (C_2^c \cup O_2^c) \\ &= (C_1 \cap O_1) \cap \left[ C_2^c \cup (O_2^c \cap C_2) \right] \\ &= \left[ C_1 \cap (O_1 \cap C_2^c) \right] \cup \left[ (C_1 \cap C_2 \cap O_2^c) \cap O_1 \right] \\ &= A \cup B, \end{aligned}C1​∩O1​∖C2​∩O2​​=(C1​∩O1​)∩(C2​∩O2​)c=(C1​∩O1​)∩(C2c​∪O2c​)=(C1​∩O1​)∩[C2c​∪(O2c​∩C2​)]=[C1​∩(O1​∩C2c​)]∪[(C1​∩C2​∩O2c​)∩O1​]=A∪B,​
where A=C1∩(O1∩C2c)∈SA = C_1 \cap (O_1 \cap C_2^c) \in \mathcal{S}A=C1​∩(O1​∩C2c​)∈S and B=(C1∩C2∩O2c)∩O1∈SB = (C_1 \cap C_2 \cap O_2^c) \cap O_1 \in \mathcal{S}B=(C1​∩C2​∩O2c​)∩O1​∈S satisfy
A∩B=∅A \cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅.

  1. Let SSS be a semiring of subsets of a set XXX, and let Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X. Show that SY={Y∩A:A∈S}S_Y = \{ Y \cap A : A \in S \}SY​={Y∩A:A∈S} is a semiring of YYY (called the restriction semiring of SSS to YYY).
Solution.

The conclusion follows from the identities:
a. Y∩∅=∅Y \cap \emptyset = \emptysetY∩∅=∅;
b. (Y∩A)∩(Y∩B)=Y∩(A∩B)(Y \cap A) \cap (Y \cap B) = Y \cap (A \cap B)(Y∩A)∩(Y∩B)=Y∩(A∩B); and
c. Y∩A∖Y∩B=Y∩(A∖B)Y \cap A \setminus Y \cap B = Y \cap (A \setminus B)Y∩A∖Y∩B=Y∩(A∖B).

  1. Let SSS be the collection of all subsets of [0,1)[0, 1)[0,1) that can be written as finite unions of subsets of [0,1)[0, 1)[0,1) of the form [a,b)[a, b)[a,b). Show that SSS is an algebra of sets but not a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.
Solution.

Let A=⋃i=1n[ai,bi)A = \bigcup_{i=1}^n [a_i, b_i)A=⋃i=1n​[ai​,bi​) and B=⋃j=1m[cj,dj)B = \bigcup_{j=1}^m [c_j, d_j)B=⋃j=1m​[cj​,dj​). Then, we have
a. A∪B∈SA \cup B \in \mathcal{S}A∪B∈S;
b. A∩B=⋃i=1n⋃j=1m[ai,bi)∩[cj,dj)∈SA \cap B = \bigcup_{i=1}^n \bigcup_{j=1}^m [a_i, b_i) \cap [c_j, d_j) \in \mathcal{S}A∩B=⋃i=1n​⋃j=1m​[ai​,bi​)∩[cj​,dj​)∈S; and
c. [0,1)∖A=⋂i=1n([0,1)∖[ai,bi))∈S[0,1) \setminus A = \bigcap_{i=1}^n \left( [0,1) \setminus [a_i, b_i) \right) \in \mathcal{S}[0,1)∖A=⋂i=1n​([0,1)∖[ai​,bi​))∈S,
  where the last membership holds since each [0,1)∖[ai,bi)[0,1) \setminus [a_i, b_i)[0,1)∖[ai​,bi​) can be written as a finite union of sets of the form [a,b)[a,b)[a,b).

To see that S\mathcal{S}S is not a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, note that
⋂n=1∞[0,1n)={0}∉S.\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} [0, \tfrac{1}{n}) = \{0\} \notin \mathcal{S}.n=1⋂∞​[0,n1​)={0}∈/S.

  1. Prove that the σ\sigmaσ-sets of the semiring
    S={[a,b):a,b∈R and a≤b}S = \{ [a, b) : a, b \in \mathbb{R} \text{ and } a \leq b \}S={[a,b):a,b∈R and a≤b}
    form a topology for the real numbers.
Solution.

Let τ\tauτ be the collection of all σ\sigmaσ-sets of SSS. Clearly, ∅∈τ\emptyset \in \tau∅∈τ and R=⋃n=1∞[−n,n)∈τ\mathbb{R} = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} [-n, n) \in \tauR=⋃n=1∞​[−n,n)∈τ. It should be clear that τ\tauτ is closed under finite intersections.
Thus, in order to establish that τ\tauτ is a topology, we need to show that τ\tauτ is closed under arbitrary unions. That is, if {[ai,bi):i∈I}\{ [a_i, b_i) : i \in I \}{[ai​,bi​):i∈I} is a collection of nonempty members of SSS, then we must show that A=⋃i∈I[ai,bi)A = \bigcup_{i \in I} [a_i, b_i)A=⋃i∈I​[ai​,bi​) belongs to τ\tauτ (i.e., that AAA is a σ\sigmaσ-set).

To see this, let V=⋃i∈I(ai,bi)V = \bigcup_{i \in I} (a_i, b_i)V=⋃i∈I​(ai​,bi​). Then, VVV is an open set, and thus, there exists an at-most countable collection of pairwise disjoint open intervals {(cj,dj):j∈J}\{ (c_j, d_j) : j \in J \}{(cj​,dj​):j∈J} (see part (g) of Problem 6.11) such that
V=⋃j∈J(cj,dj)V = \bigcup_{j \in J} (c_j, d_j)V=⋃j∈J​(cj​,dj​).
For each j∈Jj \in Jj∈J, let Aj=[cj,dj)A_j = [c_j, d_j)Aj​=[cj​,dj​) if cj=aic_j = a_icj​=ai​ for some i∈Ii \in Ii∈I, and let Aj=(cj,dj)A_j = (c_j, d_j)Aj​=(cj​,dj​) if cj≠aic_j \ne a_icj​=ai​ for all i∈Ii \in Ii∈I. Clearly, each AjA_jAj​ is a σ\sigmaσ-set. Moreover, it is easy to see that
A=⋃j∈JAjA = \bigcup_{j \in J} A_jA=⋃j∈J​Aj​
holds, which shows that AAA is a σ\sigmaσ-set.

  1. Let SSS be a semiring of subsets of a nonempty set XXX. What additional requirements must be satisfied for SSS in order to be a base for a topology on XXX? (For the definition of a base, see Exercise [18] of Section [8].) Prove that if such is the case, then each member of SSS is both open and closed in this topology.
Solution.

Since SSS is already closed under finite intersections, it follows from the definition of a base that SSS will be a base if and only if ⋃A∈SA=X\bigcup_{A \in S} A = X⋃A∈S​A=X.

Now, assume that ⋃A∈SA=X\bigcup_{A \in S} A = X⋃A∈S​A=X holds. Note first that if A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S, then (since SSS is a semiring) A∖BA \setminus BA∖B can be written as a finite union of (disjoint) members of SSS. It follows that A∖BA \setminus BA∖B belongs to the topology generated by SSS. Thus, if B∈SB \in SB∈S, then the relation

Bc=X∖B=(⋃A∈SA)∖B=⋃A∈S(A∖B),B^c = X \setminus B = \left( \bigcup_{A \in S} A \right) \setminus B = \bigcup_{A \in S} (A \setminus B),Bc=X∖B=(A∈S⋃​A)∖B=A∈S⋃​(A∖B),

shows that BcB^cBc belongs to the topology generated by SSS. That is, in this case, every B∈SB \in SB∈S is a closed and open set.

    S={E⊆X:E or Ec is at most countable}.S = \{ E \subseteq X : E \text{ or } E^c \text{ is at most countable} \}.S={E⊆X:E or Ec is at most countable}.
    Show that SSS is the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the one-point subsets of XXX.
Solution.

Clearly, SSS contains the one-point subsets of XXX, and every member of SSS must be a member of the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the one-point sets. Thus, it remains to be shown that SSS is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

Clearly, ∅,X∈S\emptyset, X \in S∅,X∈S and SSS is closed under complementation. Then let {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq S{An​}⊆S. If each AnA_nAn​ is at-most countable, then ⋃n=1∞An\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n⋃n=1∞​An​ is at-most countable, and consequently ⋃n=1∞An∈S\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in S⋃n=1∞​An​∈S. (⋃n=1∞An)c⊆(Ak)c\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right)^c \subseteq (A_k)^c(n=1⋃∞​An​)c⊆(Ak​)c
shows that ⋃n=1∞An∈S\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in S⋃n=1∞​An​∈S.

  1. Characterize the metric spaces whose open sets form a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.
Solution.

We shall show that the open sets of a metric space XXX form a σ\sigmaσ-algebra if and only if XXX is a discrete metric space (i.e., if and only if every subset of XXX is open).

Let τ\tauτ be the collection of all open sets. If τ=P(X)\tau = \mathcal{P}(X)τ=P(X), then clearly τ\tauτ is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra. On the other hand, if τ\tauτ is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, then
{x}=⋂n=1∞B(x,1n)\{x\} = \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} B(x, \tfrac{1}{n}){x}=n=1⋂∞​B(x,n1​)
shows that {x}\{x\}{x} is an open set. This easily implies that every subset of XXX is open (i.e., τ=P(X)\tau = \mathcal{P}(X)τ=P(X) holds).

  1. Determine the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the nowhere dense subsets of a topological space.
Solution.

Let XXX be a topological space. Define
A={A⊆X:A is meager or Ac is meager}.\mathcal{A} = \{ A \subseteq X : A \text{ is meager or } A^c \text{ is meager} \}.A={A⊆X:A is meager or Ac is meager}.

Recall that a set is called meager if it can be written as a countable union of nowhere dense sets—a set AAA is nowhere dense if (A‾)∘=∅(\overline{A})^\circ = \emptyset(A)∘=∅. We claim that A\mathcal{A}A is the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the nowhere dense sets of XXX. Clearly, every nowhere dense set belongs to A\mathcal{A}A, and every member of A\mathcal{A}A belongs to the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the nowhere dense sets. So, it suffices to establish that A\mathcal{A}A is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets.

Clearly, ∅,X∈A\emptyset, X \in \mathcal{A}∅,X∈A. Also, it should be obvious that A\mathcal{A}A is closed under complementation. Now, let {An}⊆A\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{A}{An​}⊆A. If each AnA_nAn​ is meager, then clearly ⋃n=1∞An∈A\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in \mathcal{A}⋃n=1∞​An​∈A. On the other hand, if (Ak)c(A_k)^c(Ak​)c is a meager set for some kkk, then the set inclusion
(⋃n=1∞An)c⊆(Ak)c\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right)^c \subseteq (A_k)^c(n=1⋃∞​An​)c⊆(Ak​)c
implies ⋃n=1∞An∈A\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in \mathcal{A}⋃n=1∞​An​∈A. Therefore, A\mathcal{A}A is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

  1. Let XXX be a nonempty set, and let F\mathcal{F}F be an uncountable collection of subsets of XXX. Show that any element of the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by F\mathcal{F}F belongs to the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by some countable subcollection of F\mathcal{F}F.
Solution.

Assume F\mathcal{F}F to be uncountable. Let A\mathcal{A}A be the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by F\mathcal{F}F. Denote by {Ai:i∈I}\{ \mathcal{A}_i : i \in I \}{Ai​:i∈I} the family of all σ\sigmaσ-algebras each of which is generated by a countable subset of F\mathcal{F}F. It suffices to show that
B=⋃i∈IAi\mathcal{B} = \bigcup_{i \in I} \mathcal{A}_iB=i∈I⋃​Ai​
is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra (because if this is the case, then A=B\mathcal{A} = \mathcal{B}A=B must hold, and the conclusion follows).

Clearly, ∅∈B\emptyset \in \mathcal{B}∅∈B. Also, if A∈BA \in \mathcal{B}A∈B, then it is easy to see that Ac∈BA^c \in \mathcal{B}Ac∈B likewise holds. Thus,
⋃n=1∞An∈Ai⊆B.\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in \mathcal{A}_i \subseteq \mathcal{B}.n=1⋃∞​An​∈Ai​⊆B.
That is, B\mathcal{B}B is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, as required.

  1. Show that every FσF_\sigmaFσ​- and every GδG_\deltaGδ​-subset of a topological space is a Borel set.
Solution.

The Borel sets are the members of the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the open sets. So, a countable intersection of open sets (or a countable union of closed sets) is always a Borel set.

  1. Show that every infinite σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets has uncountably many sets.
Solution.

Let A\mathcal{A}A be an infinite σ\sigmaσ-algebra of subsets of a set XXX. If A\mathcal{A}A contains a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of nonempty pairwise disjoint sets, then A\mathcal{A}A has uncountably many members. Indeed, if this is the case, then for each subset sss of natural numbers let
As=⋃n∈sAn∈A,A_s = \bigcup_{n \in s} A_n \in \mathcal{A},As​=n∈s⋃​An​∈A,
and note that As≠AtA_s \ne A_tAs​=At​ if s≠ts \ne ts=t. By Problem 5.6, the collection {As:s∈P(N)}\{ A_s : s \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N}) \}{As​:s∈P(N)} has uncountably many members, and so A\mathcal{A}A must likewise have uncountably many members.

Next, we shall show that there exists a sequence {Bn}⊆A\{B_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{A}{Bn​}⊆A with Bn+1⊆BnB_{n+1} \subseteq B_nBn+1​⊆Bn​ and Bn+1≠BnB_{n+1} \ne B_nBn+1​=Bn​ for all nnn. If this is done, then put An=Bn∖Bn+1A_n = B_n \setminus B_{n+1}An​=Bn​∖Bn+1​, and use the above arguments to see that A\mathcal{A}A is an uncountable set.

Using induction, we shall establish the existence of a sequence {Bn}\{B_n\}{Bn​} such that:

  1. Bn+1⊆BnB_{n+1} \subseteq B_nBn+1​⊆Bn​ and Bn+1≠BnB_{n+1} \ne B_nBn+1​=Bn​ for all nnn, and
  2. {Bn∩A:A∈A}\{ B_n \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{Bn​∩A:A∈A} is an infinite set.

The basic step of the induction is the following: Assume that Bn∈AB_n \in \mathcal{A}Bn​∈A has been chosen so that {Bn∩A:A∈A}\{ B_n \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{Bn​∩A:A∈A} has infinitely many members. Choose C∈AC \in \mathcal{A}C∈A so that
∅⊆Bn∩C⊆Bn\emptyset \subseteq B_n \cap C \subseteq B_n∅⊆Bn​∩C⊆Bn​
is a proper inclusion at both ends. In view of
Bn∩A=[(Bn∩C)∩A]∪[(Bn∖C)∩A],B_n \cap A = [(B_n \cap C) \cap A] \cup [(B_n \setminus C) \cap A],Bn​∩A=[(Bn​∩C)∩A]∪[(Bn​∖C)∩A],
we see that either {(Bn∩C)∩A:A∈A}\{ (B_n \cap C) \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{(Bn​∩C)∩A:A∈A} or {(Bn∖C)∩A:A∈A}\{ (B_n \setminus C) \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{(Bn​∖C)∩A:A∈A} is infinite.
If {(Bn∩C)∩A:A∈A}\{ (B_n \cap C) \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{(Bn​∩C)∩A:A∈A} is infinite, put Bn+1=Bn∩CB_{n+1} = B_n \cap CBn+1​=Bn​∩C.
If {(Bn∩C)∩A:A∈A}\{ (B_n \cap C) \cap A : A \in \mathcal{A} \}{(Bn​∩C)∩A:A∈A} is finite, put Bn+1=Bn∖CB_{n+1} = B_n \setminus CBn+1​=Bn​∖C.

Start the induction with B1=XB_1 = XB1​=X.

  1. Let (X,τ)(X, \tau)(X,τ) be a topological space, let B\mathcal{B}B be the σ\sigmaσ-algebra of its Borel sets, and let YYY be an arbitrary subset of XXX.     BY={A∩Y:A∈B}.\mathcal{B}_Y = \{ A \cap Y : A \in \mathcal{B} \}.BY​={A∩Y:A∈B}.
Solution.

Let (X,τ),Y(X, \tau), Y(X,τ),Y, and BY\mathcal{B}_YBY​ be as in the problem, and let
A={A∩Y:A∈B}.\mathcal{A} = \{ A \cap Y : A \in \mathcal{B} \}.A={A∩Y:A∈B}.

C={A∈B:A∩Y∈BY}.\mathcal{C} = \{ A \in \mathcal{B} : A \cap Y \in \mathcal{B}_Y \}.C={A∈B:A∩Y∈BY​}.

  1. Let A1,…,AnA_1, \ldots, A_nA1​,…,An​ be sets in some semiring SSS. Show that there exists a finite number of pairwise disjoint sets B1,…,BmB_1, \ldots, B_mB1​,…,Bm​ of SSS such that each AiA_iAi​ can be written as a union of sets from the B1,…,BmB_1, \ldots, B_mB1​,…,Bm​.
    [HINT: Use induction on nnn and Theorem 12.2(1).]
Solution.

Solution. We use induction on nnn. For n=1n = 1n=1 the result is trivial. Thus, assume that the result is true for some nnn, and let A1,…,An,An+1A_1, \ldots, A_n, A_{n+1}A1​,…,An​,An+1​ be members of S\mathcal{S}S.
Pick a finite number of pairwise disjoint members B1,…,BmB_1, \ldots, B_mB1​,…,Bm​ of S\mathcal{S}S such that each AiA_iAi​, 1≤i≤n1 \le i \le n1≤i≤n, can be written as a union of sets from B1,…,BmB_1, \ldots, B_mB1​,…,Bm​. Clearly,
⋃i=1nAi⊆⋃j=1mBj.\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \subseteq \bigcup_{j=1}^m B_j.i=1⋃n​Ai​⊆j=1⋃m​Bj​.
The sets B1∩An+1,…,Bm∩An+1B_1 \cap A_{n+1}, \ldots, B_m \cap A_{n+1}B1​∩An+1​,…,Bm​∩An+1​ are pairwise disjoint members of S\mathcal{S}S. On the other hand, for each 1≤i≤m1 \le i \le m1≤i≤m there exists a finite pairwise disjoint collection Fi⊆S\mathcal{F}_i \subseteq \mathcal{S}Fi​⊆S with
Bi∖An+1=⋃C∈FiCB_i \setminus A_{n+1} = \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{F}_i} CBi​∖An+1​=C∈Fi​⋃​C
(by the definition of the semiring). Thus, the collection
F=F1∪⋯∪Fm∪{B1∩An+1,…,Bm∩An+1}⊆S\mathcal{F} = \mathcal{F}_1 \cup \cdots \cup \mathcal{F}_m \cup \{ B_1 \cap A_{n+1}, \ldots, B_m \cap A_{n+1} \} \subseteq \mathcal{S}F=F1​∪⋯∪Fm​∪{B1​∩An+1​,…,Bm​∩An+1​}⊆S
is finite and pairwise disjoint. Moreover, each AiA_iAi​ (1≤i≤n1 \le i \le n1≤i≤n) can be written as a union of members of F\mathcal{F}F. Now, observe that
An+1=(An+1∖⋃j=1mBj)∪(B1∩An+1)∪⋯∪(Bm∩An+1).A_{n+1} = \left( A_{n+1} \setminus \bigcup_{j=1}^m B_j \right) \cup (B_1 \cap A_{n+1}) \cup \cdots \cup (B_m \cap A_{n+1}).An+1​=(An+1​∖j=1⋃m​Bj​)∪(B1​∩An+1​)∪⋯∪(Bm​∩An+1​).

By Theorem 12.2(1) there exist pairwise disjoint sets D1,…,Dk∈SD_1, \ldots, D_k \in \mathcal{S}D1​,…,Dk​∈S such that
An+1∖⋃j=1mBj=⋃r=1kDr.A_{n+1} \setminus \bigcup_{j=1}^m B_j = \bigcup_{r=1}^k D_r.An+1​∖j=1⋃m​Bj​=r=1⋃k​Dr​.
Finally, the collection
F∪{D1,…,Dk}⊆S\mathcal{F} \cup \{ D_1, \ldots, D_k \} \subseteq \mathcal{S}F∪{D1​,…,Dk​}⊆S
is finite and pairwise disjoint, and each set AiA_iAi​ (1≤i≤n+11 \le i \le n+11≤i≤n+1) can be written as a union from these sets.

13. MEASURES ON SEMIRINGS

The semirings would not be of importance to us if it were not for the purpose of defining measures on them. The concept of a measure can be thought of as a generalization of the concepts of length and area, and its definition is given next. A real-valued function defined on a family of sets is referred to as a set function.

Definition 13.1. Let SSS be a semiring of subsets of a set XXX. A set function μ:S→[0,∞]\mu: S \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] is called a measure on SSS if it satisfies the following properties:

  1. μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0, and
  2. whenever {An}\{A_n\}{An​} is a disjoint sequence of SSS satisfying ⋃n=1∞An∈S\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in S⋃n=1∞​An​∈S, then
    μ(⋃n=1∞An)=∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n)μ(n=1⋃∞​An​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
    holds; that is, μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive.

A triplet (X,S,μ)(X, S, \mu)(X,S,μ), where XXX is a nonempty set, SSS is a semiring of subsets of XXX, and μ\muμ is a measure on SSS is called a measure space.

Theorem 13.2. For a measure space (X,S,μ)(X, S, \mu)(X,S,μ), the following statements hold:

  1. If A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S are pairwise disjoint and ⋃i=1nAi∈S\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \in S⋃i=1n​Ai​∈S, then
    μ(⋃i=1nAi)=∑i=1nμ(Ai).\mu\left( \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \right) = \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i).μ(i=1⋃n​Ai​)=i=1∑n​μ(Ai​).
    That is, μ\muμ is finitely additive.

  2. If A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S satisfy A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then μ(A)≤μ(B)\mu(A) \leq \mu(B)μ(A)≤μ(B) holds. That is, μ\muμ is monotone.

Proof

(1) If A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S are pairwise disjoint sets such that ⋃i=1nAi∈S\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \in S⋃i=1n​Ai​∈S, let Ai=∅A_i = \emptysetAi​=∅ for i>ni > ni>n. Then {Ai}\{A_i\}{Ai​} is a disjoint sequence of SSS satisfying ⋃i=1∞Ai=⋃i=1nAi∈S\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i = \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \in S⋃i=1∞​Ai​=⋃i=1n​Ai​∈S. Thus, by the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ, we have
μ(⋃i=1nAi)=μ(⋃i=1∞Ai)=∑i=1∞μ(Ai)=∑i=1nμ(Ai),\mu\left( \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \right) = \mu\left( \bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i \right) = \sum_{i=1}^\infty \mu(A_i) = \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i),μ(i=1⋃n​Ai​)=μ(i=1⋃∞​Ai​)=i=1∑∞​μ(Ai​)=i=1∑n​μ(Ai​),
where the last equality holds by virtue of μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.

(2) Let A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S satisfy A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B. Choose a finite collection of disjoint sets C1,…,CnC_1, \ldots, C_nC1​,…,Cn​ of SSS such that B∖A=⋃i=1nCiB \setminus A = \bigcup_{i=1}^n C_iB∖A=⋃i=1n​Ci​. Then
B=A∪(B∖A)=A∪C1∪⋯∪CnB = A \cup (B \setminus A) = A \cup C_1 \cup \cdots \cup C_nB=A∪(B∖A)=A∪C1​∪⋯∪Cn​
is a finite union of disjoint sets of SSS. Thus, from part (1) we have
μ(B)=μ(A)+μ(C1)+⋯+μ(Cn)≥μ(A),\mu(B) = \mu(A) + \mu(C_1) + \cdots + \mu(C_n) \geq \mu(A),μ(B)=μ(A)+μ(C1​)+⋯+μ(Cn​)≥μ(A),
and the proof of the theorem is complete.

We continue with some examples of measure spaces.

Example 13.3 (The Counting Measure).
Let XXX be a set, and let S=P(X)\mathcal{S} = \mathcal{P}(X)S=P(X). Define
μ:S→[0,∞] by μ(A)={∞if A is an infinite subset of X,∣A∣if A is a finite set.\mu : \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty] \text{ by } \mu(A) = \begin{cases} \infty & \text{if } A \text{ is an infinite subset of } X, \\ |A| & \text{if } A \text{ is a finite set}. \end{cases}μ:S→[0,∞] by μ(A)={∞∣A∣​if A is an infinite subset of X,if A is a finite set.​
The reader can verify easily that (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a measure space.■\blacksquare■

The measure of the next example is known as a Dirac measure.

Example 13.4 (The Dirac Measure).
Let XXX be a nonempty set, and let S=P(X)\mathcal{S} = \mathcal{P}(X)S=P(X). Fix an element a∈Xa \in Xa∈X, and define
μ:S→[0,∞) by μ(A)={0if a∉A,1if a∈A.\mu : \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty) \text{ by } \mu(A) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } a \notin A, \\ 1 & \text{if } a \in A. \end{cases}μ:S→[0,∞) by μ(A)={01​if a∈/A,if a∈A.​
It is easy to see that (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a measure space.■\blacksquare■

Example 13.5.
Let F\mathcal{F}F be a nonempty pairwise disjoint family of subsets of a set XXX, and let
S=F∪{∅}.\mathcal{S} = \mathcal{F} \cup \{ \emptyset \}.S=F∪{∅}.
In Example 12 we verified that S\mathcal{S}S is a semiring. Now, for each nonempty set A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F fix some mA∈[0,∞]m_A \in [0, \infty]mA​∈[0,∞]. Then the set function
μ:S→[0,∞)\mu : \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty)μ:S→[0,∞)

μ(∅)=0andμ(A)=mA if A∈S is nonempty,\mu(\emptyset) = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad \mu(A) = m_A \text{ if } A \in \mathcal{S} \text{ is nonempty},μ(∅)=0andμ(A)=mA​ if A∈S is nonempty,
is a measure.

Proof

To see this, note that if A∈SA \in SA∈S can be written as a disjoint union A=⋃n=1∞AnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA=⋃n=1∞​An​ with {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq S{An​}⊆S, then it must be the case that A=AkA = A_kA=Ak​ for some kkk and An=∅A_n = \emptysetAn​=∅ for n≠kn \ne kn=k. This easily implies
μ(A)=μ(Ak)=∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu(A) = \mu(A_k) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n)μ(A)=μ(Ak​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
and so μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive.■\blacksquare■

Example 13.6. Assume that the function f:R→Rf : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}f:R→R is nondecreasing and left continuous; that is, lim⁡x↑af(x)=f(a)\lim_{x \uparrow a} f(x) = f(a)limx↑a​f(x)=f(a) holds for each a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R. Consider the semiring
S={[a,b):a,b∈R and a≤b};S = \{[a, b) : a, b \in \mathbb{R} \text{ and } a \leq b\};S={[a,b):a,b∈R and a≤b};
see Example 12.9. Now define μ:S→[0,∞)\mu : S \to [0, \infty)μ:S→[0,∞) by μ([a,b))=f(b)−f(a)\mu([a, b)) = f(b) - f(a)μ([a,b))=f(b)−f(a) if a<ba < ba<b and μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0. We claim that the set function μ\muμ is a measure.

Proof

To see that μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive, let a<ba < ba<b and let
[a,b)=⋃n=1∞[an,bn)[a, b) = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [a_n, b_n)[a,b)=n=1⋃∞​[an​,bn​)
with the sequence {[an,bn)}\{[a_n, b_n)\}{[an​,bn​)} disjoint; we can assume that an<bna_n < b_nan​<bn​ for each nnn. Let
s=∑n=1∞μ([an,bn)).s = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu([a_n, b_n)).s=n=1∑∞​μ([an​,bn​)).

Rearranging [a1,b1),…,[ak,bk)[a_1, b_1), \ldots, [a_k, b_k)[a1​,b1​),…,[ak​,bk​), we can suppose that
a1<b1≤a2<b2≤⋯≤ak<bk.a_1 < b_1 \leq a_2 < b_2 \leq \cdots \leq a_k < b_k.a1​<b1​≤a2​<b2​≤⋯≤ak​<bk​.
Since fff is increasing,
∑i=1k[f(bi)−f(ai)]≤f(bk)−f(a1)≤f(b)−f(a),\sum_{i=1}^k [f(b_i) - f(a_i)] \leq f(b_k) - f(a_1) \leq f(b) - f(a),i=1∑k​[f(bi​)−f(ai​)]≤f(bk​)−f(a1​)≤f(b)−f(a),
which implies
s≤f(b)−f(a)=μ([a,b)).(★)s \leq f(b) - f(a) = \mu([a, b)). \tag{★}s≤f(b)−f(a)=μ([a,b)).(★)

For the reverse inequality, let δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 and 0<ϵ<b−a0 < \epsilon < b - a0<ϵ<b−a. For each nnn choose some cn<anc_n < a_ncn​<an​ satisfying
f(an)−f(x)<2−nδwhenever cn<x≤an.f(a_n) - f(x) < 2^{-n} \delta \quad \text{whenever } c_n < x \leq a_n.f(an​)−f(x)<2−nδwhenever cn​<x≤an​.
Since [a,b−ϵ]⊆⋃n=1∞(cn,bn)[a, b - \epsilon] \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty (c_n, b_n)[a,b−ϵ]⊆⋃n=1∞​(cn​,bn​) and [a,b−ϵ][a, b - \epsilon][a,b−ϵ] is compact, it follows that
[a,b−ϵ]⊆⋃n=1k(cn,bn)[a, b - \epsilon] \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^k (c_n, b_n)[a,b−ϵ]⊆n=1⋃k​(cn​,bn​)
must hold for some kkk. Assume a1=aa_1 = aa1​=a. If b1<b−ϵb_1 < b - \epsilonb1​<b−ϵ, then by rearranging, we can assume b1∈(c2,b2)b_1 \in (c_2, b_2)b1​∈(c2​,b2​). Since (a1,b1)∩(a2,b2)=∅(a_1, b_1) \cap (a_2, b_2) = \emptyset(a1​,b1​)∩(a2​,b2​)=∅, it follows that c2<b1≤a2c_2 < b_1 \leq a_2c2​<b1​≤a2​. Continuing this process, we obtain
(c1,b1),…,(cm,bm),1≤m≤k,(c_1, b_1), \ldots, (c_m, b_m), \quad 1 \leq m \leq k,(c1​,b1​),…,(cm​,bm​),1≤m≤k,
with b−ϵ≤bmb - \epsilon \leq b_mb−ϵ≤bm​ and, if m≥2m \geq 2m≥2, ci+1<bi<ai+1c_{i+1} < b_i < a_{i+1}ci+1​<bi​<ai+1​ for 1≤i≤m−11 \leq i \leq m - 11≤i≤m−1; note that
∑i=1m−1[f(ai+1)−f(bi)]≤δ.\sum_{i=1}^{m-1} [f(a_{i+1}) - f(b_i)] \leq \delta.i=1∑m−1​[f(ai+1​)−f(bi​)]≤δ.
Consequently,
s≥∑i=1m[f(bi)−f(ai)]=f(bm)−f(a1)−∑i=1m−1[f(ai+1)−f(bi)]>f(b−ϵ)−f(a)−δ.s \geq \sum_{i=1}^m [f(b_i) - f(a_i)] = f(b_m) - f(a_1) - \sum_{i=1}^{m-1} [f(a_{i+1}) - f(b_i)] > f(b - \epsilon) - f(a) - \delta.s≥i=1∑m​[f(bi​)−f(ai​)]=f(bm​)−f(a1​)−i=1∑m−1​[f(ai+1​)−f(bi​)]>f(b−ϵ)−f(a)−δ.

Since δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 and 0<ϵ<b−a0 < \epsilon < b - a0<ϵ<b−a are arbitrary, the left continuity of fff at bbb implies
s≥f(b)−f(a).s \geq f(b) - f(a).s≥f(b)−f(a).
The latter combined with (★)\text{(★)}(★) shows that s=f(b)−f(a)s = f(b) - f(a)s=f(b)−f(a), so μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive.■\blacksquare■

An important special case of the preceding example is the case when f(x)=xf(x) = xf(x)=x for all x∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R. The resulting measure is called the Lebesgue measure on S\mathcal{S}S, and it will be denoted by λ\lambdaλ; that is, λ([a,b))=b−a\lambda([a, b)) = b - aλ([a,b))=b−a. Later, the domain of this measure will be extended to include all the open and closed sets.

Example 13.7. Consider the semiring SSS of Example 12.10. That is, the semiring SSS consists of all subsets of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn of the form
[a1,b1)×⋯×[an,bn),[a_1, b_1) \times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n),[a1​,b1​)×⋯×[an​,bn​),
with ai<bia_i < b_iai​<bi​ for 1≤i≤n1 \le i \le n1≤i≤n, together with the empty set. Define λ:S→[0,∞)\lambda : S \to [0, \infty)λ:S→[0,∞) by λ(∅)=0\lambda(\emptyset) = 0λ(∅)=0 and
λ([a1,b1)×⋯×[an,bn))=∏i=1n(bi−ai).\lambda([a_1, b_1) \times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n)) = \prod_{i=1}^n (b_i - a_i).λ([a1​,b1​)×⋯×[an​,bn​))=i=1∏n​(bi​−ai​).

Then λ\lambdaλ is called the Lebesgue measure on SSS.

The following theorem characterizes the set functions on semirings that are measures:

Theorem 13.8. Let SSS be a semiring, and let μ:S→[0,∞]\mu : S \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] be a set function. Then μ\muμ is a measure on SSS if and only if μ\muμ satisfies the following conditions:

  1. μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.
  2. If A∈SA \in SA∈S and A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S satisfy ⋃i=1nAi⊆A\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \subseteq A⋃i=1n​Ai​⊆A and Ai∩Aj=∅A_i \cap A_j = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅ for i≠ji \ne ji=j, then
    ∑i=1nμ(Ai)≤μ(A)\sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i) \leq \mu(A)i=1∑n​μ(Ai​)≤μ(A)
    holds.
  3. If A∈SA \in SA∈S and {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq S{An​}⊆S satisfy A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, then
    μ(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n)μ(A)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
    holds; that is, μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-subadditive.
Proof

Assume that μ\muμ is a measure on SSS. Then by definition, μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.

For (2), assume that A∈SA \in SA∈S, and that the disjoint sets A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S satisfy ⋃i=1nAi⊆A\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \subseteq A⋃i=1n​Ai​⊆A. By Theorem 12.2(1), there exist disjoint sets B1,…,Bm∈SB_1, \ldots, B_m \in SB1​,…,Bm​∈S such that
A∖⋃i=1nAi=⋃i=1mBi.A \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i = \bigcup_{i=1}^m B_i.A∖i=1⋃n​Ai​=i=1⋃m​Bi​.
Put C1=A1,…,Cn=AnC_1 = A_1, \ldots, C_n = A_nC1​=A1​,…,Cn​=An​, and Cn+i=BiC_{n+i} = B_iCn+i​=Bi​ for 1≤i≤m1 \le i \le m1≤i≤m. Then the sets C1,…,Cn+mC_1, \ldots, C_{n+m}C1​,…,Cn+m​ are disjoint and
A=⋃i=1n+mCi.A = \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+m} C_i.A=i=1⋃n+m​Ci​.
By the finite additivity property of μ\muμ (see Theorem 13.2), we get
μ(A)=∑i=1n+mμ(Ci)≥∑i=1nμ(Ai).\mu(A) = \sum_{i=1}^{n+m} \mu(C_i) \ge \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i).μ(A)=i=1∑n+m​μ(Ci​)≥i=1∑n​μ(Ai​).

For the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ\muμ, assume that A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​ holds with A∈SA \in SA∈S and {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq S{An​}⊆S. Put B1=A1B_1 = A_1B1​=A1​ and
Bn+1=An+1∖⋃i=1nAifor n≥1.B_{n+1} = A_{n+1} \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \quad \text{for } n \ge 1.Bn+1​=An+1​∖i=1⋃n​Ai​for n≥1.
Then ⋃n=1∞Bn=⋃n=1∞An\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_n = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n⋃n=1∞​Bn​=⋃n=1∞​An​ and Bn⊆AnB_n \subseteq A_nBn​⊆An​ for each nnn. Also, the sequence {Bn}\{B_n\}{Bn​} is disjoint, and by Theorem 12.2(1), for each n≥2n \ge 2n≥2 there exist pairwise disjoint sets C1n,…,Cknn∈SC_1^n, \ldots, C_{k_n}^n \in SC1n​,…,Ckn​n​∈S such that
Bn=⋃i=1knCin.B_n = \bigcup_{i=1}^{k_n} C_i^n.Bn​=i=1⋃kn​​Cin​.
Note that by (2) and ⋃i=1knCin⊆An\bigcup_{i=1}^{k_n} C_i^n \subseteq A_n⋃i=1kn​​Cin​⊆An​ for each nnn, it follows that
∑i=1knμ(Cin)≤μ(An).\sum_{i=1}^{k_n} \mu(C_i^n) \le \mu(A_n).i=1∑kn​​μ(Cin​)≤μ(An​).
(For n=1n = 1n=1, we put k1=1k_1 = 1k1​=1 and C11=A1C_1^1 = A_1C11​=A1​.)

Now, observe that
A=⋃n=1∞(Bn∩A)=⋃n=1∞⋃i=1kn(Cin∩A),A = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty (B_n \cap A) = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \bigcup_{i=1}^{k_n} (C_i^n \cap A),A=n=1⋃∞​(Bn​∩A)=n=1⋃∞​i=1⋃kn​​(Cin​∩A),
is a disjoint union. So, by the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ, we get
μ(A)=∑n=1∞∑i=1knμ(Cin∩A)≤∑n=1∞∑i=1knμ(Cin)≤∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu(A) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sum_{i=1}^{k_n} \mu(C_i^n \cap A) \le \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sum_{i=1}^{k_n} \mu(C_i^n) \le \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n).μ(A)=n=1∑∞​i=1∑kn​​μ(Cin​∩A)≤n=1∑∞​i=1∑kn​​μ(Cin​)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​).

Conversely, if the set function μ:S→[0,∞]\mu : S \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] satisfies the above three conditions, then μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive by combining (2) and (3). Hence, μ\muμ is a measure.■\blacksquare■

We close the section with the definition of a finitely additive measure.
A set function μ:S→[0,∞],\mu : S \to [0, \infty],μ:S→[0,∞], where SSS is a semiring, is called a finitely additive measure on SSS if it satisfies these properties:
a. μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.
b. If A1,…,An∈SA_1, \ldots, A_n \in SA1​,…,An​∈S are disjoint and ⋃i=1nAi∈S\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i \in S⋃i=1n​Ai​∈S, then
μ(⋃i=1nAi)=∑i=1nμ(Ai).\mu\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right) = \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i).μ(i=1⋃n​Ai​)=i=1∑n​μ(Ai​).

EXERCISES
  1. Let {an}\{a_n\}{an​} be a sequence of nonnegative real numbers. Set μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0, and for every nonempty subset AAA of N\mathbb{N}N put μ(A)=∑n∈Aan\mu(A) = \sum_{n \in A} a_nμ(A)=∑n∈A​an​. Show that μ:P(N)→[0,∞]\mu: \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N}) \to [0, \infty]μ:P(N)→[0,∞] is a measure.
Solution.

If {An}\{A_n\}{An​} is a sequence of pairwise disjoint subsets of N\mathbb{N}N and
A=⋃n=1∞An,A = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n,A=n=1⋃∞​An​,
then note that
μ(A)=∑k∈Aak=∑n=1∞(∑k∈Anak)=∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu(A) = \sum_{k \in A} a_k = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left( \sum_{k \in A_n} a_k \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ(A)=k∈A∑​ak​=n=1∑∞​(k∈An​∑​ak​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​).

  1. Let S\mathcal{S}S be a semiring, and let μ:S→[0,∞]\mu: \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] be a set function such that μ(A)<∞\mu(A) < \inftyμ(A)<∞ for some A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S. If μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive, then show that μ\muμ is a measure.
Solution.

Write
A=A∪∅∪∅∪⋯ .A = A \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \cdots.A=A∪∅∪∅∪⋯.
Then,
μ(A)=μ(A)+μ(∅)+μ(∅)+⋯ .\mu(A) = \mu(A) + \mu(\emptyset) + \mu(\emptyset) + \cdots.μ(A)=μ(A)+μ(∅)+μ(∅)+⋯.

If μ(∅)>0\mu(\emptyset) > 0μ(∅)>0, then μ(A)=∞\mu(A) = \inftyμ(A)=∞, contrary to our hypothesis. Thus,
μ(∅)=0,\mu(\emptyset) = 0,μ(∅)=0,
and so μ\muμ is a measure.

  1. Let XXX be an uncountable set, and let the σ\sigmaσ-algebra
    S={E⊆X:E or Ec is at most countable};\mathcal{S} = \{E \subseteq X : E \text{ or } E^c \text{ is at most countable} \};S={E⊆X:E or Ec is at most countable};
    see also Exercise 7 of Section 12. Show that μ:S→[0,∞)\mu: \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty)μ:S→[0,∞), defined by μ(E)=0\mu(E) = 0μ(E)=0 if EEE is at most countable and μ(E)=1\mu(E) = 1μ(E)=1 if EcE^cEc is at most countable, is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.
Solution.

Clearly, μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0. For the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ, let {En}⊆S\{E_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{En​}⊆S be a pairwise disjoint sequence. Let
E=⋃n=1∞En.E = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n.E=n=1⋃∞​En​.

μ(E)=∑n=1∞μ(En)=0\mu(E) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(E_n) = 0μ(E)=n=1∑∞​μ(En​)=0
holds. On the other hand, if EkcE_k^cEkc​ is at-most countable for some kkk, then (in view of En∩Ek=∅E_n \cap E_k = \emptysetEn​∩Ek​=∅ for n≠kn \ne kn=k) we must have En⊆EkcE_n \subseteq E_k^cEn​⊆Ekc​ for n≠kn \ne kn=k, and so EnE_nEn​ is at-most countable for each n≠kn \ne kn=k. Thus,
1=μ(E)=μ(Ek)=∑n=1∞μ(En).1 = \mu(E) = \mu(E_k) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(E_n).1=μ(E)=μ(Ek​)=n=1∑∞​μ(En​).

It is interesting to observe that if X=[0,1]X = [0, 1]X=[0,1], then S\mathcal{S}S is a σ\sigmaσ-subalgebra of the Lebesgue measurable subsets of [0,1][0, 1][0,1], and μ\muμ is the restriction of the Lebesgue measure to S\mathcal{S}S.

  1. Let XXX be a nonempty set, and let f:X→[0,∞]f : X \to [0, \infty]f:X→[0,∞] be a function. Define
    μ:P(X)→[0,∞] by\mu : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty] \text{ by}μ:P(X)→[0,∞] by
    μ(A)={∑x∈Af(x)if A≠∅ and is at-most countable,∞if A is uncountable,0if A=∅.\mu(A) = \begin{cases} \sum_{x \in A} f(x) & \text{if } A \ne \emptyset \text{ and is at-most countable}, \\ \infty & \text{if } A \text{ is uncountable}, \\ 0 & \text{if } A = \emptyset. \end{cases}μ(A)=⎩⎨⎧​∑x∈A​f(x)∞0​if A=∅ and is at-most countable,if A is uncountable,if A=∅.​

Show that μ\muμ is a measure.

Solution.

A=⋃n=1∞An.A = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n.A=n=1⋃∞​An​.
If some AnA_nAn​ is uncountable, then AAA is likewise uncountable, and hence, in this case
μ(A)=∑n=1∞μ(An)=∞\mu(A) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) = \inftyμ(A)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​)=∞
holds.

On the other hand, if each AnA_nAn​ is at-most countable, then AAA is also at-most countable, and so
μ(A)=∑x∈Af(x)=∑n=1∞[∑x∈Anf(x)]=∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu(A) = \sum_{x \in A} f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left[ \sum_{x \in A_n} f(x) \right] = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n)μ(A)=x∈A∑​f(x)=n=1∑∞​[x∈An​∑​f(x)]=n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
also holds.

  1. Let S\mathcal{S}S be a semiring, and let μ:S→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] be a finitely additive measure.
    Show that if μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-subadditive, then μ\muμ is a measure.
Solution.

Let {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S be a pairwise disjoint sequence such that
A=⋃n=1∞An∈S.A = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \in \mathcal{S}.A=n=1⋃∞​An​∈S.
By hypothesis,
μ(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n)μ(A)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
holds. On the other hand, if kkk is fixed, then there exist pairwise disjoint sets B1,…,Bm∈SB_1, \ldots, B_m \in \mathcal{S}B1​,…,Bm​∈S such that
A∖⋃n=1kAn=⋃i=1mBiA \setminus \bigcup_{n=1}^{k} A_n = \bigcup_{i=1}^{m} B_iA∖n=1⋃k​An​=i=1⋃m​Bi​
(see Theorem 12.2). Since
A=[⋃n=1kAn]∪[⋃i=1mBi]A = \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{k} A_n \right] \cup \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{m} B_i \right]A=[n=1⋃k​An​]∪[i=1⋃m​Bi​]
is a finite union of pairwise disjoint members of S\mathcal{S}S, the finite additivity of μ\muμ implies
∑n=1kμ(An)≤∑n=1kμ(An)+∑i=1mμ(Bi)=μ(A).\sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(A_n) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(A_n) + \sum_{i=1}^{m} \mu(B_i) = \mu(A).n=1∑k​μ(An​)≤n=1∑k​μ(An​)+i=1∑m​μ(Bi​)=μ(A).

Since kkk is arbitrary,
∑n=1∞μ(An)≤μ(A)\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) \leq \mu(A)n=1∑∞​μ(An​)≤μ(A)
also holds, and so μ\muμ is a measure.

  1. Let {μn}\{\mu_n\}{μn​} be an increasing sequence of measures on a semiring S\mathcal{S}S; that is, μn(A)≤μn+1(A)\mu_n(A) \le \mu_{n+1}(A)μn​(A)≤μn+1​(A) holds for all A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S and all nnn. Define μ:S→[0,∞]\mu: \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] by μ(A)=sup⁡{μn(A)}\mu(A) = \sup \{\mu_n(A)\}μ(A)=sup{μn​(A)} for each A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S. Show that μ\muμ is a measure.
Solution.

Clearly, μ(∅)=0\mu(\varnothing) = 0μ(∅)=0. Now, let {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S be a pairwise disjoint sequence such that
⋃n=1∞An=A∈S.\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n = A \in \mathcal{S}.n=1⋃∞​An​=A∈S.
Since each μi\mu_iμi​ is a measure,
μi(A)=∑n=1∞μi(An)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu_i(A) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu_i(A_n) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n)μi​(A)=n=1∑∞​μi​(An​)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​)
holds, and so
μ(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ(A)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​).
On the other hand, for each kkk, we have
∑n=1kμ(An)=lim⁡i→∞∑n=1kμi(An)=lim⁡i→∞μi(⋃n=1kAn)≤μ(A).\sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(A_n) = \lim_{i \to \infty} \sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu_i(A_n) = \lim_{i \to \infty} \mu_i\left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{k} A_n\right) \leq \mu(A).n=1∑k​μ(An​)=i→∞lim​n=1∑k​μi​(An​)=i→∞lim​μi​(n=1⋃k​An​)≤μ(A).
Thus,
∑n=1∞μ(An)≤μ(A)\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) \leq \mu(A)n=1∑∞​μ(An​)≤μ(A)
also holds, which shows that the measure μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive.

  1. Consider the semiring S={A⊆R:A is at most countable}\mathcal{S} = \{A \subseteq \mathbb{R} : A \text{ is at most countable}\}S={A⊆R:A is at most countable}, and define the set function μ:S→[0,∞]\mu: \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] by μ(A)=0\mu(A) = 0μ(A)=0 if AAA is finite and μ(A)=∞\mu(A) = \inftyμ(A)=∞ if AAA is countable. Show that μ\muμ is a finitely additive measure that is not a measure.
Solution.

Let A1,…,AnA_1, \ldots, A_nA1​,…,An​ be pairwise disjoint members of S\mathcal{S}S. Put
A=⋃i=1nAi.A = \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i.A=i=1⋃n​Ai​.
If each AiA_iAi​ is a finite set, then AAA is likewise a finite set, and
∑i=1nμ(Ai)=μ(A)=0\sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i) = \mu(A) = 0i=1∑n​μ(Ai​)=μ(A)=0
holds. On the other hand, if one of the AiA_iAi​ is countable, then AAA itself is also countable, and
∑i=1nμ(Ai)=μ(A)=∞\sum_{i=1}^n \mu(A_i) = \mu(A) = \inftyi=1∑n​μ(Ai​)=μ(A)=∞
holds. Thus, μ\muμ is a finitely additive measure.

To see that μ\muμ is not σ\sigmaσ-additive, note that
N=⋃n=1∞{n},\mathbb{N} = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \{n\},N=n=1⋃∞​{n},
while
0=∑n=1∞μ({n})<μ(N)=∞.0 = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(\{n\}) < \mu(\mathbb{N}) = \infty.0=n=1∑∞​μ({n})<μ(N)=∞.

  1. Show that every finitely additive measure is monotone.
Solution.

Assume that μ:S→[0,∞]\mu : S \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] is a finitely additive measure. Let A,B∈SA, B \in SA,B∈S satisfy A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B. Choose a finite collection of disjoint sets C1,…,CnC_1, \ldots, C_nC1​,…,Cn​ of SSS such that
B∖A=⋃i=1nCi.B \setminus A = \bigcup_{i=1}^n C_i.B∖A=i=1⋃n​Ci​.
Then,
B=A∪C1∪⋯∪CnB = A \cup C_1 \cup \cdots \cup C_nB=A∪C1​∪⋯∪Cn​
is a finite union of pairwise disjoint sets of SSS. Thus, by the finite additivity of μ\muμ, we have
μ(A)≤μ(A)+μ(C1)+⋯+μ(Cn)=μ(B).\mu(A) \leq \mu(A) + \mu(C_1) + \cdots + \mu(C_n) = \mu(B).μ(A)≤μ(A)+μ(C1​)+⋯+μ(Cn​)=μ(B).

  1. Consider the set function μ\muμ defined in Example 13. That is, consider a nondecreasing and left-continuous function f:R→Rf: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}f:R→R and then define the set function μ:S→[0,∞)\mu: \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty)μ:S→[0,∞) by μ((a,b))=f(b)−f(a)\mu((a, b)) = f(b) - f(a)μ((a,b))=f(b)−f(a), where S\mathcal{S}S is the semiring S={(a,b):−∞<a<b<∞}\mathcal{S} = \{(a, b): -\infty < a < b < \infty\}S={(a,b):−∞<a<b<∞}. Prove alternately the fact that μ\muμ is a measure.
Solution.

An alternate way of proving the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ is as follows. Let a<ba < ba<b and let
[a,b)=⋃n=1∞[an,bn)[a, b) = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} [a_n, b_n)[a,b)=n=1⋃∞​[an​,bn​)
with the sequence {[an,bn)}\{[a_n, b_n)\}{[an​,bn​)} pairwise disjoint. For each a<x≤ba < x \leq ba<x≤b let
sx=∑i[f(bi)−f(ai)],s_x = \sum_i \left[ f(b_i) - f(a_i) \right],sx​=i∑​[f(bi​)−f(ai​)],
where the sum (possibly a series) extends over all iii for which [ai,bi)⊆[a,x)[a_i, b_i) \subseteq [a, x)[ai​,bi​)⊆[a,x) holds; we let sx=0s_x = 0sx​=0 if there is no such interval. Since fff is nondecreasing, we have
sx≤f(x)−f(a).s_x \leq f(x) - f(a).sx​≤f(x)−f(a).
Next, note that the set
A={x∈(a,b]:sx=f(x)−f(a)}A = \{ x \in (a, b] : s_x = f(x) - f(a) \}A={x∈(a,b]:sx​=f(x)−f(a)}
is nonempty. Let t=sup⁡At = \sup At=supA, and note that a<t≤ba < t \leq ba<t≤b. Now, for x∈Ax \in Ax∈A, we have
f(x)−f(a)=sx≤st≤f(t)−f(a),f(x) - f(a) = s_x \leq s_t \leq f(t) - f(a),f(x)−f(a)=sx​≤st​≤f(t)−f(a),
and so, by the left-continuity of fff, we get st=f(t)−f(a)s_t = f(t) - f(a)st​=f(t)−f(a). That is, t∈At \in At∈A.

Our objective is to establish that t=bt = bt=b holds. Assume by way of contradiction that a<t<ba < t < ba<t<b. Then ak≤t<bka_k \leq t < b_kak​≤t<bk​ must hold for some kkk. Since the sequence {[an,bn)}\{[a_n, b_n)\}{[an​,bn​)} is pairwise disjoint, observe that [ai,bi)⊆[a,t)[a_i, b_i) \subseteq [a, t)[ai​,bi​)⊆[a,t) holds if and only if [ai,bi)⊆[a,ak)[a_i, b_i) \subseteq [a, a_k)[ai​,bi​)⊆[a,ak​). Thus, st=saks_t = s_{a_k}st​=sak​​ holds. In particular, the relation
f(t)−f(a)=st=sak≤f(ak)−f(a)≤f(t)−f(a)f(t) - f(a) = s_t = s_{a_k} \leq f(a_k) - f(a) \leq f(t) - f(a)f(t)−f(a)=st​=sak​​≤f(ak​)−f(a)≤f(t)−f(a)
guarantees that ak∈Aa_k \in Aak​∈A. However, this implies bk∈Ab_k \in Abk​∈A, which is impossible. Therefore, t=bt = bt=b holds, which guarantees that
μ([a,b))=∑n=1∞μ([an,bn)).\mu([a, b)) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu([a_n, b_n)).μ([a,b))=n=1∑∞​μ([an​,bn​)).

14. OUTER MEASURES AND MEASURABLE SETS

The theory of outer measures will be presented in this section. The concept of an outer measure is due to C. Carathéodory and is defined as follows.

Definition 14.1 (Carathéodory). A set function μ:P(X)→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]μ:P(X)→[0,∞] defined on the power set P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) of some set XXX is called an outer measure if it satisfies these properties:
a. μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.
b. μ(A)≤μ(B)\mu(A) \le \mu(B)μ(A)≤μ(B) if A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B; that is, μ\muμ is monotone.
c. μ(⋃n=1∞An)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n \right) \le \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n)μ(⋃n=1∞​An​)≤∑n=1∞​μ(An​) holds for every sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of subsets of XXX; that is, μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-subadditive.

An outer measure μ\muμ need not be σ\sigmaσ-additive on P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X). However, as we shall see, there always exists a σ\sigmaσ-algebra of subsets (called the measurable sets) on which μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive. The details will be explained below.

Throughout the rest of this section, μ\muμ will denote a fixed outer measure. The next definition describes the measurable sets and is also due to C. Carathéodory.

Definition 14.2 (Carathéodory). A subset E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X is called measurable (more precisely, μ\muμ-measurable) whenever
μ(A)=μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)\mu(A) = \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c)μ(A)=μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)
holds for all A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X.

Since the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ\muμ implies
μ(A)=μ((A∩E)∪(A∩Ec))≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)\mu(A) = \mu((A \cap E) \cup (A \cap E^c)) \leq \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c)μ(A)=μ((A∩E)∪(A∩Ec))≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)
for all subsets AAA and EEE, it easily follows that a subset EEE is measurable if and only if
μ(A)≥μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)\mu(A) \geq \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c)μ(A)≥μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)
holds for each subset AAA of XXX.

The collection of all measurable sets will be denoted by Λ\LambdaΛ. That is,
Λ={E⊆X:μ(A)=μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec) for all A⊆X}.\Lambda = \{ E \subseteq X : \mu(A) = \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c) \text{ for all } A \subseteq X \}.Λ={E⊆X:μ(A)=μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec) for all A⊆X}.

If clarity requires μ\muμ to be indicated, then we shall write Λμ\Lambda_\muΛμ​ instead of Λ\LambdaΛ.

The simplest measurable sets are the sets having outer measure zero. Before verifying this, we name these sets.

Definition 14.3. A set EEE is called a null set if μ(E)=0\mu(E) = 0μ(E)=0.

It should be clear from the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity property of μ\muμ that a countable union of null sets is again a null set. The null sets will play an important role in the theory of integration.

Theorem 14.4. Every null set is measurable.

Proof

Let E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X with μ(E)=0\mu(E) = 0μ(E)=0. Then the monotonicity of μ\muμ implies μ(A∩E)=0\mu(A \cap E) = 0μ(A∩E)=0 for each A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. Consequently, for each subset AAA of XXX, we have
μ(A)≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)=μ(A∩Ec)≤μ(A),\mu(A) \leq \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c) = \mu(A \cap E^c) \leq \mu(A),μ(A)≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)=μ(A∩Ec)≤μ(A),
where the first inequality holds by virtue of the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ\muμ. Thus, EEE is measurable.

For more properties of the measurable sets, we need the following:

Lemma 14.5. Let the sets E1,…,EnE_1, \ldots, E_nE1​,…,En​ be disjoint and measurable. Then

μ(⋃i=1n(A∩Ei))=∑i=1nμ(A∩Ei)\mu\left( \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} (A \cap E_i) \right) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu(A \cap E_i)μ(i=1⋃n​(A∩Ei​))=i=1∑n​μ(A∩Ei​)

holds for every subset AAA of XXX.

Proof

The proof is by induction on nnn. Obviously, the result is true for n=1n = 1n=1. Assume it now true for some nnn, and let the sets E1,…,En,En+1E_1, \ldots, E_n, E_{n+1}E1​,…,En​,En+1​ be disjoint and measurable. If A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X, then
A∩[⋃i=1n+1Ei]∩En+1=A∩En+1A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} E_i \right] \cap E_{n+1} = A \cap E_{n+1}A∩[i=1⋃n+1​Ei​]∩En+1​=A∩En+1​
A∩[⋃i=1n+1Ei]∩(En+1)c=A∩[⋃i=1nEi]A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} E_i \right] \cap (E_{n+1})^c = A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} E_i \right]A∩[i=1⋃n+1​Ei​]∩(En+1​)c=A∩[i=1⋃n​Ei​]

Therefore, using the measurability of En+1E_{n+1}En+1​, we see that
μ(⋃i=1n+1(A∩Ei))=μ(A∩[⋃i=1n+1Ei])\mu \left( \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} (A \cap E_i) \right) = \mu \left( A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} E_i \right] \right)μ(i=1⋃n+1​(A∩Ei​))=μ(A∩[i=1⋃n+1​Ei​])
=μ(A∩[⋃i=1n+1Ei]∩En+1)+μ(A∩[⋃i=1n+1Ei]∩(En+1)c)= \mu \left( A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} E_i \right] \cap E_{n+1} \right) + \mu \left( A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n+1} E_i \right] \cap (E_{n+1})^c \right)=μ(A∩[i=1⋃n+1​Ei​]∩En+1​)+μ(A∩[i=1⋃n+1​Ei​]∩(En+1​)c)
=μ(A∩En+1)+μ(A∩[⋃i=1nEi])=∑i=1n+1μ(A∩Ei),= \mu(A \cap E_{n+1}) + \mu \left( A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} E_i \right] \right) = \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} \mu(A \cap E_i),=μ(A∩En+1​)+μ(A∩[i=1⋃n​Ei​])=i=1∑n+1​μ(A∩Ei​),

where the last equality holds by the induction hypothesis. The induction is now complete, and the proof is finished.

We are now ready to establish that the collection of all measurable sets is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

Theorem 14.6. The collection Λ\LambdaΛ of all measurable sets is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

Proof

It should be clear from the definition of the measurable sets that if
E∈ΛE \in \LambdaE∈Λ, then Ec∈ΛE^c \in \LambdaEc∈Λ; that is, Λ\LambdaΛ is closed under complementation. Since μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0, we have ∅∈Λ\emptyset \in \Lambda∅∈Λ; therefore, X∈ΛX \in \LambdaX∈Λ.
Next, we show that if E1,E2∈ΛE_1, E_2 \in \LambdaE1​,E2​∈Λ, then E=E1∪E2∈ΛE = E_1 \cup E_2 \in \LambdaE=E1​∪E2​∈Λ. Indeed, note first that
E=E1∪(E1c∩E2)E = E_1 \cup (E_1^c \cap E_2)E=E1​∪(E1c​∩E2​), and then that for every subset AAA of XXX the relations
μ(A)≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)\mu(A) \leq \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c)μ(A)≤μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)
≤[μ(A∩E1)+μ((A∩E1c)∩E2)]+μ((A∩E1c)∩E2c)\leq \left[ \mu(A \cap E_1) + \mu((A \cap E_1^c) \cap E_2) \right] + \mu((A \cap E_1^c) \cap E_2^c)≤[μ(A∩E1​)+μ((A∩E1c​)∩E2​)]+μ((A∩E1c​)∩E2c​)
=μ(A∩E1)+[μ((A∩E1c)∩E2)+μ((A∩E1c)∩E2c)]= \mu(A \cap E_1) + \left[ \mu((A \cap E_1^c) \cap E_2) + \mu((A \cap E_1^c) \cap E_2^c) \right]=μ(A∩E1​)+[μ((A∩E1c​)∩E2​)+μ((A∩E1c​)∩E2c​)]
=μ(A∩E1)+μ(A∩E1c)=μ(A)= \mu(A \cap E_1) + \mu(A \cap E_1^c) = \mu(A)=μ(A∩E1​)+μ(A∩E1c​)=μ(A)
imply E1∪E2∈ΛE_1 \cup E_2 \in \LambdaE1​∪E2​∈Λ.

It now follows easily that Λ\LambdaΛ is closed under finite unions and finite intersections (E1∩E2=(E1c∪E2c)c)(E_1 \cap E_2 = (E_1^c \cup E_2^c)^c )(E1​∩E2​=(E1c​∪E2c​)c). Also, if E1,E2∈ΛE_1, E_2 \in \LambdaE1​,E2​∈Λ, then E1∖E2=E1∩E2c∈ΛE_1 \setminus E_2 = E_1 \cap E_2^c \in \LambdaE1​∖E2​=E1​∩E2c​∈Λ. Thus, Λ\LambdaΛ is an algebra of sets.

To finish the proof, it remains to be shown that Λ\LambdaΛ is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra of sets. To this end, let {En}⊆Λ\{ E_n \} \subseteq \Lambda{En​}⊆Λ. Put E=⋃n=1∞EnE = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_nE=⋃n=1∞​En​, and define G1=E1G_1 = E_1G1​=E1​ and Gn+1=En+1∖⋃i=1nEiG_{n+1} = E_{n+1} \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} E_iGn+1​=En+1​∖⋃i=1n​Ei​ for n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Then {Gn}⊆Λ\{ G_n \} \subseteq \Lambda{Gn​}⊆Λ, Gn∩Gm=∅G_n \cap G_m = \emptysetGn​∩Gm​=∅ if n≠mn \neq mn=m, and
E=⋃n=1∞GnE = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} G_nE=⋃n=1∞​Gn​. Let Fn=⋃i=1nGiF_n = \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} G_iFn​=⋃i=1n​Gi​ for n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, and note that each FnF_nFn​ is a measurable set such that ⋃n=1∞Fn=E\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} F_n = E⋃n=1∞​Fn​=E. Now if A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X, then
μ(A)=μ(A∩Fn)+μ(A∩Fnc)\mu(A) = \mu(A \cap F_n) + \mu(A \cap F_n^c)μ(A)=μ(A∩Fn​)+μ(A∩Fnc​)
≥μ(A∩Fn)+μ(A∩Ec)\geq \mu(A \cap F_n) + \mu(A \cap E^c)≥μ(A∩Fn​)+μ(A∩Ec)
=[∑i=1nμ(A∩Gi)]+μ(A∩Ec)= \left[ \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu(A \cap G_i) \right] + \mu(A \cap E^c)=[i=1∑n​μ(A∩Gi​)]+μ(A∩Ec)

holds for each nnn, where the last equality holds by virtue of Lemma 14.5. Hence,

μ(A)≥[∑i=1∞μ(A∩Gi)]+μ(A∩Ec)≥μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)≥μ(A),\mu(A) \geq \left[ \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \mu(A \cap G_i) \right] + \mu(A \cap E^c) \geq \mu(A \cap E) + \mu(A \cap E^c) \geq \mu(A),μ(A)≥[i=1∑∞​μ(A∩Gi​)]+μ(A∩Ec)≥μ(A∩E)+μ(A∩Ec)≥μ(A),

and so E∈ΛE \in \LambdaE∈Λ. Therefore, Λ\LambdaΛ is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

Remarkably, the outer measure μ\muμ restricted to Λ\LambdaΛ is a measure.

Theorem 14.7. Let μ\muμ be an outer measure on XXX. Then (X,Λ,μ)(X, \Lambda, \mu)(X,Λ,μ) is a measure space; that is, μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-additive on Λ\LambdaΛ.

Proof

Let {En}\{E_n\}{En​} be a disjoint sequence of Λ\LambdaΛ. Put
E=⋃n=1∞En.E = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n.E=n=1⋃∞​En​.
By the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity property of μ\muμ we have
μ(E)≤∑n=1∞μ(En).\mu(E) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(E_n).μ(E)≤n=1∑∞​μ(En​).

On the other hand, Lemma 14.5 shows that
∑n=1kμ(En)=∑n=1kμ(E∩En)=μ(E∩[⋃n=1kEn])≤μ(E)\sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(E_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(E \cap E_n) = \mu \left( E \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{k} E_n \right] \right) \leq \mu(E)n=1∑k​μ(En​)=n=1∑k​μ(E∩En​)=μ(E∩[n=1⋃k​En​])≤μ(E)
holds for every kkk. Hence,
∑n=1∞μ(En)≤μ(E),\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(E_n) \leq \mu(E),n=1∑∞​μ(En​)≤μ(E),
so that
μ(E)=∑n=1∞μ(En),\mu(E) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(E_n),μ(E)=n=1∑∞​μ(En​),
and the proof is finished.

When μ\muμ is restricted to Λ\LambdaΛ, it is often referred to as the measure induced by the outer measure μ\muμ.
It is useful to know that μ\muμ is subtractive on the measurable sets of finite measure.

Theorem 14.8. Let AAA and BBB be measurable sets such that A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, with μ(B)<∞\mu(B) < \inftyμ(B)<∞. Then
μ(B∖A)=μ(B)−μ(A)\mu(B \setminus A) = \mu(B) - \mu(A)μ(B∖A)=μ(B)−μ(A)holds.

Proof

Write B=A∪(B∖A)B = A \cup (B \setminus A)B=A∪(B∖A), and then use the additivity of μ\muμ to get
μ(B)=μ(A)+μ(B∖A).\mu(B) = \mu(A) + \mu(B \setminus A).μ(B)=μ(A)+μ(B∖A).
Since μ(B)<∞\mu(B) < \inftyμ(B)<∞, it follows that
μ(B∖A)=μ(B)−μ(A).\mu(B \setminus A) = \mu(B) - \mu(A).μ(B∖A)=μ(B)−μ(A).

We are now ready to describe a process of constructing outer measures. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a collection of subsets of a set XXX containing the empty set. Also, let μ ⁣:F→[0,∞]\mu \colon \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞] be a set function such that μ(∅)=0\mu(\varnothing) = 0μ(∅)=0. For every subset AAA of XXX, we define

μ∗(A)=inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An} is a sequence of F with A⊆⋃n=1∞An}.\mu^*(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \text{ is a sequence of } \mathcal{F} \text{ with } A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right\}.μ∗(A)=inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​} is a sequence of F with A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}.

If there is no sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of F\mathcal{F}F such that A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, then we let μ∗(A)=∞\mu^*(A) = \inftyμ∗(A)=∞. That is, we adhere to the convention inf⁡∅=∞\inf \varnothing = \inftyinf∅=∞.

Theorem 14.9 (Carathéodory). The set function
μ∗:P(X)→[0,∞]\mu^* : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]μ∗:P(X)→[0,∞]is an outer measure (called the outer measure generated by the set function μ:F→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞]) satisfying
μ∗(A)≤μ(A)\mu^*(A) \leq \mu(A)μ∗(A)≤μ(A) for each A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F.

Proof

Clearly, μ∗(A)≥0\mu^*(A) \geq 0μ∗(A)≥0 holds for every A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. If An=∅A_n = \emptysetAn​=∅ for all nnn, then
0≤μ∗(∅)≤∑n=1∞μ(∅)=0,0 \leq \mu^*(\emptyset) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(\emptyset) = 0,0≤μ∗(∅)≤n=1∑∞​μ(∅)=0,
so that μ∗(∅)=0\mu^*(\emptyset) = 0μ∗(∅)=0.

For the monotonicity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, assume A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B. If B⊆⋃n=1∞AnB \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nB⊆⋃n=1∞​An​ with {An}⊆F\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F}{An​}⊆F, then
A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, and so
μ∗(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu^*(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ∗(A)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​).
(If there is no sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of F\mathcal{F}F that covers BBB, then μ∗(B)=∞\mu^*(B) = \inftyμ∗(B)=∞, and μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)\mu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(B)μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B) is obvious.) Thus,
μ∗(B)=inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An}⊆F and B⊆⋃n=1∞An}≥μ∗(A).\mu^*(B) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F} \text{ and } B \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right\} \geq \mu^*(A).μ∗(B)=inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​}⊆F and B⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}≥μ∗(A).

For the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, let {An}\{A_n\}{An​} be an arbitrary sequence of subsets of XXX. If ∑n=1∞μ∗(An)=∞\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(A_n) = \infty∑n=1∞​μ∗(An​)=∞, then clearly,
μ∗(⋃n=1∞An)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(An).\mu^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(A_n).μ∗(n=1⋃∞​An​)≤n=1∑∞​μ∗(An​).
Therefore, assume ∑n=1∞μ∗(An)<∞\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(A_n) < \infty∑n=1∞​μ∗(An​)<∞. Let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. For each iii, choose a sequence {Ani}\{A_n^i\}{Ani​} of F\mathcal{F}F such that
Ai⊆⋃n=1∞AniA_i \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^iAi​⊆⋃n=1∞​Ani​, and
∑n=1∞μ(Ani)≤μ∗(Ai)+2−iϵ.\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^i) \leq \mu^*(A_i) + 2^{-i} \epsilon.n=1∑∞​μ(Ani​)≤μ∗(Ai​)+2−iϵ.
Then Ani∈FA_n^i \in \mathcal{F}Ani​∈F for each iii and nnn, and
⋃n=1∞An⊆⋃i=1∞⋃n=1∞Ani.\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^i.n=1⋃∞​An​⊆i=1⋃∞​n=1⋃∞​Ani​.
Hence,
μ∗(⋃n=1∞An)≤∑i=1∞∑n=1∞μ(Ani)=∑i=1∞μ∗(Ai)+ϵ\mu^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^i) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(A_i) + \epsilonμ∗(n=1⋃∞​An​)≤i=1∑∞​n=1∑∞​μ(Ani​)=i=1∑∞​μ∗(Ai​)+ϵ
for all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, so that
μ∗(⋃n=1∞An)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(An).\mu^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(A_n).μ∗(n=1⋃∞​An​)≤n=1∑∞​μ∗(An​).
Since
A=A∪∅∪∅∪∅∪⋯ ,A = A \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \cdots,A=A∪∅∪∅∪∅∪⋯,
it easily follows that
μ∗(A)≤μ(A)\mu^*(A) \leq \mu(A)μ∗(A)≤μ(A)
holds true for each A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F.

It is easy to construct examples where
μ∗(A)<μ(A)\mu^*(A) < \mu(A)μ∗(A)<μ(A)
is valid for some A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F, i.e., μ∗\mu^*μ∗ need not be (in general) an extension of μ\muμ. For instance, if
X={1,2,3},F={∅,{1},{1,2}}X = \{1,2,3\}, \quad \mathcal{F} = \{\emptyset, \{1\}, \{1,2\}\}X={1,2,3},F={∅,{1},{1,2}}
and
μ:F→[0,∞] is defined by μ(∅)=0, μ({1})=2, μ({1,2})=1,\mu : \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty] \text{ is defined by } \mu(\emptyset) = 0, \, \mu(\{1\}) = 2, \, \mu(\{1,2\}) = 1,μ:F→[0,∞] is defined by μ(∅)=0,μ({1})=2,μ({1,2})=1,
then
μ∗({1})=1.\mu^*(\{1\}) = 1.μ∗({1})=1.
However, as we shall see in the next section, when μ\muμ is a measure, the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is always an extension of μ\muμ.

It turns out that the outer measure generated by μ∗\mu^*μ∗ coincides with μ∗\mu^*μ∗, i.e.,
(μ∗)∗=μ∗.(\mu^*)^* = \mu^*.(μ∗)∗=μ∗.
The details follow.

Theorem 14.10. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a collection of subsets of a set XXX containing the empty set and let
μ ⁣:F→[0,∞]\mu \colon \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞] be a set function satisfying μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0. Assume Φ\PhiΦ is also a collection of subsets of XXX with F⊆Φ\mathcal{F} \subseteq \PhiF⊆Φ and that
ν ⁣:Φ→[0,∞]\nu \colon \Phi \to [0, \infty]ν:Φ→[0,∞] denotes the restriction of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ to Φ\PhiΦ, i.e., ν(A)=μ∗(A)\nu(A) = \mu^*(A)ν(A)=μ∗(A) for each A∈ΦA \in \PhiA∈Φ. Then the outer measure generated by ν\nuν coincides with μ∗\mu^*μ∗, i.e.,
ν∗(A)=μ∗(A)\nu^*(A) = \mu^*(A)ν∗(A)=μ∗(A) holds for each subset AAA of XXX.

Proof

Let A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. We first claim that
μ∗(A)≤ν∗(A).\mu^*(A) \leq \nu^*(A).μ∗(A)≤ν∗(A).
If ν∗(A)=∞\nu^*(A) = \inftyν∗(A)=∞, then the inequality is obvious. So, assume ν∗(A)<∞\nu^*(A) < \inftyν∗(A)<∞. In this case, note that if a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of Φ\PhiΦ satisfies A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, then the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ implies μ∗(A)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(An)=∑n=1∞ν(An)\mu^*(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu^*(A_n) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \nu(A_n)μ∗(A)≤∑n=1∞​μ∗(An​)=∑n=1∞​ν(An​). Therefore,
μ∗(A)≤inf⁡{∑n=1∞ν(An):{An}⊆Φ and A⊆⋃n=1∞An}=ν∗(A).\mu^*(A) \leq \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \nu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \subseteq \Phi \text{ and } A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n \right\} = \nu^*(A).μ∗(A)≤inf{n=1∑∞​ν(An​):{An​}⊆Φ and A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}=ν∗(A).

Next, we shall show that
ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A)\nu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(A)ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A)
is also true. Again, if μ∗(A)=∞\mu^*(A) = \inftyμ∗(A)=∞, then the inequality is obvious. So, assume μ∗(A)<∞\mu^*(A) < \inftyμ∗(A)<∞ and let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Then there exists a sequence {An}⊆F⊆Φ\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F} \subseteq \Phi{An​}⊆F⊆Φ satisfying A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​ and ∑n=1∞μ(An)<μ∗(A)+ϵ\sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) < \mu^*(A) + \epsilon∑n=1∞​μ(An​)<μ∗(A)+ϵ. Now, taking into account (from Theorem 14.9) that μ∗(An)≤μ(An)\mu^*(A_n) \leq \mu(A_n)μ∗(An​)≤μ(An​) holds for each nnn, we see that
ν∗(A)≤∑n=1∞ν(An)=∑n=1∞μ∗(An)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)<μ∗(A)+ϵ.\nu^*(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \nu(A_n) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu^*(A_n) \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) < \mu^*(A) + \epsilon.ν∗(A)≤n=1∑∞​ν(An​)=n=1∑∞​μ∗(An​)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​)<μ∗(A)+ϵ.

Since ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 is arbitrary, it follows that ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A)\nu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(A)ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A). Thus, ν∗(A)=μ∗(A)\nu^*(A) = \mu^*(A)ν∗(A)=μ∗(A) holds for all subsets AAA of XXX.

Finally, we leave it as an exercise for the reader to prove the following result asserting that the only outer measures are the ones generated by set functions.

Theorem 14.11. Let ν:P(X)→[0,∞]\nu : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]ν:P(X)→[0,∞] be a set function on the power set of a set XXX. Then ν\nuν is an outer measure if and only if there exist a family F\mathcal{F}F of subsets of XXX and a set function μ:F→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞], where ∅∈F\emptyset \in \mathcal{F}∅∈F and μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0, whose generating outer measure coincides with ν\nuν, i.e., ν=μ∗\nu = \mu^*ν=μ∗.

EXERCISES

Unless otherwise stated, in the exercises below μ\muμ is assumed to be an outer measure on some set XXX.

  1. Show that a countable union of null sets is again a null set.
Solution.

The conclusion follows from the inequality
μ(⋃n=1∞An)≤∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ(n=1⋃∞​An​)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​).

  1. If AAA is a null set, then show that
    μ(B)=μ(A∪B)=μ(B∖A)\mu(B) = \mu(A \cup B) = \mu(B \setminus A)μ(B)=μ(A∪B)=μ(B∖A)
    holds for every subset BBB of XXX.
Solution.

The conclusion follows from the inequalities:
μ(B)≤μ(B∪A)=μ((B∖A)∪A)\mu(B) \leq \mu(B \cup A) = \mu((B \setminus A) \cup A)μ(B)≤μ(B∪A)=μ((B∖A)∪A)
≤μ(B∖A)+μ(A)=μ(B∖A)≤μ(B).\leq \mu(B \setminus A) + \mu(A) = \mu(B \setminus A) \leq \mu(B).≤μ(B∖A)+μ(A)=μ(B∖A)≤μ(B).

  1. If a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of subsets of XXX satisfies ∑n=1∞μ(An)<∞\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) < \infty∑n=1∞​μ(An​)<∞, then show that the set
    {x∈X:x belongs to An for infinitely many n}\{ x \in X : x \text{ belongs to } A_n \text{ for infinitely many } n \}{x∈X:x belongs to An​ for infinitely many n}
    is a null set.
Solution.

Assume that a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} satisfies
∑n=1∞μ(An)<∞.\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) < \infty.n=1∑∞​μ(An​)<∞.
For each nnn, let
En=⋃i=n∞Ai,E_n = \bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} A_i,En​=i=n⋃∞​Ai​,
and note that E⊆EnE \subseteq E_nE⊆En​ holds for each nnn. Therefore,
0≤μ(E)≤μ(En)≤∑i=n∞μ(Ai)⟶0,0 \leq \mu(E) \leq \mu(E_n) \leq \sum_{i=n}^{\infty} \mu(A_i) \longrightarrow 0,0≤μ(E)≤μ(En​)≤i=n∑∞​μ(Ai​)⟶0,
and hence
μ(E)=0.\mu(E) = 0.μ(E)=0.

  1. If EEE is a measurable subset of XXX, then show that for every subset AAA of XXX the following equality holds:
    μ(E∪A)+μ(E∩A)=μ(E)+μ(A).\mu(E \cup A) + \mu(E \cap A) = \mu(E) + \mu(A).μ(E∪A)+μ(E∩A)=μ(E)+μ(A).
Solution.

The measurability of EEE gives
μ(E∪A)=μ((E∪A)∩E)+μ((E∪A)∩Ec)=μ(E)+μ(A∩Ec).\mu(E \cup A) = \mu((E \cup A) \cap E) + \mu((E \cup A) \cap E^c) = \mu(E) + \mu(A \cap E^c).μ(E∪A)=μ((E∪A)∩E)+μ((E∪A)∩Ec)=μ(E)+μ(A∩Ec).

Consequently, we have
μ(E∪A)+μ(E∩A)=μ(E)+μ(A∩Ec)+μ(A∩E)=μ(E)+μ(A).\mu(E \cup A) + \mu(E \cap A) = \mu(E) + \mu(A \cap E^c) + \mu(A \cap E) = \mu(E) + \mu(A).μ(E∪A)+μ(E∩A)=μ(E)+μ(A∩Ec)+μ(A∩E)=μ(E)+μ(A).

  1. If AAA is a nonmeasurable subset of XXX and EEE is a measurable set such that A⊆EA \subseteq EA⊆E, then show that μ(E∖A)>0\mu(E \setminus A) > 0μ(E∖A)>0.
Solution.

If μ(E∖A)=0\mu(E \setminus A) = 0μ(E∖A)=0 holds, then E∖A∈ΛE \setminus A \in \LambdaE∖A∈Λ. Thus,
A=E∖(E∖A)∈Λ,A = E \setminus (E \setminus A) \in \Lambda,A=E∖(E∖A)∈Λ,
which is a contradiction. Therefore,
μ(E∖A)>0.\mu(E \setminus A) > 0.μ(E∖A)>0.

  1. Let AAA be a subset of XXX, and let {En}\{E_n\}{En​} be a disjoint sequence of measurable sets. Show that
    μ(⋃n=1∞(A∩En))=∑n=1∞μ(A∩En).\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} (A \cap E_n) \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A \cap E_n).μ(n=1⋃∞​(A∩En​))=n=1∑∞​μ(A∩En​).
Solution.

From the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ\muμ, we see that
μ(A∩[⋃n=1∞En])=μ(⋃n=1∞(A∩En))≤∑n=1∞μ(A∩En).\mu\left(A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right] \right) = \mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} (A \cap E_n) \right) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A \cap E_n).μ(A∩[n=1⋃∞​En​])=μ(n=1⋃∞​(A∩En​))≤n=1∑∞​μ(A∩En​).

On the other hand, Lemma 14.5 implies
∑n=1kμ(A∩En)=μ(A∩[⋃n=1kEn])≤μ(A∩[⋃n=1∞En])\sum_{n=1}^{k} \mu(A \cap E_n) = \mu\left(A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{k} E_n \right] \right) \leq \mu\left(A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right] \right)n=1∑k​μ(A∩En​)=μ(A∩[n=1⋃k​En​])≤μ(A∩[n=1⋃∞​En​])
for each kkk, and so
∑n=1∞μ(A∩En)≤μ(A∩[⋃n=1∞En])\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A \cap E_n) \leq \mu\left(A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right] \right)n=1∑∞​μ(A∩En​)≤μ(A∩[n=1⋃∞​En​])
also holds.

  1. Let {An}\{A_n\}{An​} be a sequence of subsets of XXX. Assume that there exists a disjoint sequence {Bn}\{B_n\}{Bn​} of measurable sets such that An⊆BnA_n \subseteq B_nAn​⊆Bn​ holds for each nnn. Show that
    μ(⋃n=1∞An)=∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ(n=1⋃∞​An​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​).
Solution.

Put
A=⋃n=1∞AnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA=n=1⋃∞​An​
and note that A∩Bn=AnA \cap B_n = A_nA∩Bn​=An​ holds for each nnn. Thus, using the preceding problem, we see that
μ(⋃n=1∞An)=μ(A∩[⋃n=1∞Bn])=∑n=1∞μ(A∩Bn)=∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right) = \mu\left( A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} B_n \right] \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A \cap B_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ(n=1⋃∞​An​)=μ(A∩[n=1⋃∞​Bn​])=n=1∑∞​μ(A∩Bn​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​).

  1. Show that a subset EEE of XXX is measurable if and only if for each ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 there exists a measurable set FFF such that F⊆EF \subseteq EF⊆E, and μ(E∖F)<ϵ\mu(E \setminus F) < \epsilonμ(E∖F)<ϵ.
Solution.

If EEE is measurable, then F=EF = EF=E satisfies the condition for each ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0.
For the converse, assume that the condition is satisfied.

Start by choosing for each nnn a measurable set FnF_nFn​ with Fn⊆EF_n \subseteq EFn​⊆E and
μ(E∖Fn)<1n.\mu(E \setminus F_n) < \frac{1}{n}.μ(E∖Fn​)<n1​.
Put
F=⋃n=1∞Fn⊆E,F = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} F_n \subseteq E,F=n=1⋃∞​Fn​⊆E,
and note that FFF is measurable. Consequently,
μ(E∖F)≤μ(E∖Fn)<1n for each n\mu(E \setminus F) \leq \mu(E \setminus F_n) < \frac{1}{n} \text{ for each } nμ(E∖F)≤μ(E∖Fn​)<n1​ for each n
implies μ(E∖F)=0\mu(E \setminus F) = 0μ(E∖F)=0, and so E∖FE \setminus FE∖F is measurable.
The measurability of EEE now follows from the identity
E=F∪(E∖F).E = F \cup (E \setminus F).E=F∪(E∖F).

An alternate proof of the preceding part goes as follows.
Let AAA be a subset of XXX with μ(A)<∞\mu(A) < \inftyμ(A)<∞. If ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 is given, pick a measurable subset FFF with F⊆EF \subseteq EF⊆E and μ(E∖F)<ε\mu(E \setminus F) < \varepsilonμ(E∖F)<ε. Then

  1. Assume that a subset EEE of XXX has the property that for each ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, there exists a measurable set FFF such that μ(E△F)<ϵ\mu(E \triangle F) < \epsilonμ(E△F)<ϵ. Show that EEE is a measurable set.

  1.
