  1. Prove Theorem 14.11.
    Let ν:P(X)→[0,∞]\nu : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]ν:P(X)→[0,∞] be a set function. Show that ν\nuν is an outer measure if and only if there exist a collection F\mathcal{F}F of subsets of XXX containing the empty set and a set function
    μ:F→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞]
    with μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0 satisfying
    ν(A)=μ∗(A)for all A∈P(X).\nu(A) = \mu^*(A) \quad \text{for all } A \in \mathcal{P}(X).ν(A)=μ∗(A)for all A∈P(X).
Solution.

Assume first that ν:P(X)→[0,∞]\nu : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]ν:P(X)→[0,∞] is an outer measure. Let F=P(X)\mathcal{F} = \mathcal{P}(X)F=P(X) and μ=ν\mu = \nuμ=ν. We claim that
ν(A)=μ∗(A)\nu(A) = \mu^*(A)ν(A)=μ∗(A)
holds for each A∈P(X)A \in \mathcal{P}(X)A∈P(X), where
μ∗(A)=inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An}⊆F, A⊆⋃n=1∞An},\mu^*(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F},\, A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right\},μ∗(A)=inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​}⊆F,A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​},
and inf⁡∅=∞\inf \emptyset = \inftyinf∅=∞.

To see this, let A∈P(X)A \in \mathcal{P}(X)A∈P(X). From
A=A∪∅∪∅∪⋯ ,A = A \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \cdots,A=A∪∅∪∅∪⋯,
we see that
μ∗(A)≤μ(A)=ν(A).\mu^*(A) \leq \mu(A) = \nu(A).μ∗(A)≤μ(A)=ν(A).
On the other hand, if A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​ holds true, then from the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of ν\nuν, we see that
ν(A)≤∑n=1∞ν(An)=∑n=1∞μ(An),\nu(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(A_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n),ν(A)≤n=1∑∞​ν(An​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​),
and so ν(A)≤μ∗(A)\nu(A) \leq \mu^*(A)ν(A)≤μ∗(A) is also true. Hence, ν(A)=μ∗(A)\nu(A) = \mu^*(A)ν(A)=μ∗(A) for each subset AAA of XXX.

For the converse, assume that the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ generated by a set function
μ:F→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞]
satisfies μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0 and ν(A)=μ∗(A)\nu(A) = \mu^*(A)ν(A)=μ∗(A) for each A∈P(X)A \in \mathcal{P}(X)A∈P(X).
We shall show that ν\nuν is an outer measure by verifying the three properties required to be satisfied by ν\nuν in order to be a measure:

(1) Zero on the empty set:
0≤ν(∅)=μ∗(∅)≤μ(∅)+μ(∅)+⋯=0,0 \leq \nu(\emptyset) = \mu^*(\emptyset) \leq \mu(\emptyset) + \mu(\emptyset) + \cdots = 0,0≤ν(∅)=μ∗(∅)≤μ(∅)+μ(∅)+⋯=0,
so we see that ν(∅)=0\nu(\emptyset) = 0ν(∅)=0.

(2) Monotonicity:
Let A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B and let {An}\{A_n\}{An​} be a sequence of F\mathcal{F}F with
B⊆⋃n=1∞An.B \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n.B⊆n=1⋃∞​An​.
Then A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, and so
μ∗(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An).\mu^*(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).μ∗(A)≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​).
Therefore,
ν(A)=μ∗(A)≤inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An}⊆F, B⊆⋃n=1∞An}=μ∗(B)=ν(B).\nu(A) = \mu^*(A) \leq \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F},\, B \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right\} = \mu^*(B) = \nu(B).ν(A)=μ∗(A)≤inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​}⊆F,B⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}=μ∗(B)=ν(B).
(If there is no sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of F\mathcal{F}F with B⊆⋃n=1∞AnB \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nB⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, then μ∗(B)=∞\mu^*(B) = \inftyμ∗(B)=∞, and ν(A)≤ν(B)\nu(A) \leq \nu(B)ν(A)≤ν(B) is trivially true.)

(3) σ\sigmaσ-Subadditivity:
Let {En}\{E_n\}{En​} be a sequence of subsets of XXX, and let
E=⋃n=1∞En.E = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n.E=n=1⋃∞​En​.
If
∑n=1∞μ∗(En)=∞,\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(E_n) = \infty,n=1∑∞​μ∗(En​)=∞,
then
ν(E)=μ∗(E)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(En)=∑n=1∞ν(En)\nu(E) = \mu^*(E) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(E_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(E_n)ν(E)=μ∗(E)≤n=1∑∞​μ∗(En​)=n=1∑∞​ν(En​)
is trivially true. So, assume
∑n=1∞μ∗(En)<∞,\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(E_n) < \infty,n=1∑∞​μ∗(En​)<∞,
and let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. For each nnn, pick a sequence {Ank}\{A_n^k\}{Ank​} of F\mathcal{F}F with
En⊆⋃k=1∞Ankand∑k=1∞μ(Ank)<μ∗(En)+2−nε=ν(En)+2−nε.E_n \subseteq \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} A_n^k \quad \text{and} \quad \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^k) < \mu^*(E_n) + 2^{-n} \varepsilon = \nu(E_n) + 2^{-n} \varepsilon.En​⊆k=1⋃∞​Ank​andk=1∑∞​μ(Ank​)<μ∗(En​)+2−nε=ν(En​)+2−nε.

Clearly,
E⊆⋃n=1∞⋃k=1∞Ank,E \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} A_n^k,E⊆n=1⋃∞​k=1⋃∞​Ank​,
and so
ν(E)=μ∗(E)≤∑n=1∞∑k=1∞μ(Ank)<∑n=1∞[ν(En)+2−nε]=∑n=1∞ν(En)+ε.\begin{aligned} \nu(E) &= \mu^*(E) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^k) \\ &< \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} [\nu(E_n) + 2^{-n} \varepsilon] = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(E_n) + \varepsilon. \end{aligned}ν(E)​=μ∗(E)≤n=1∑∞​k=1∑∞​μ(Ank​)<n=1∑∞​[ν(En​)+2−nε]=n=1∑∞​ν(En​)+ε.​

Since ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 is arbitrary,
ν(E)≤∑n=1∞ν(En),\nu(E) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(E_n),ν(E)≤n=1∑∞​ν(En​),
and we are done.

  1. Let A\mathcal{A}A be the collection of all measurable subsets of XXX of finite measure. That is,
    A={A∈Λ:μ(A)<∞}.\mathcal{A} = \{ A \in \Lambda : \mu(A) < \infty \}.A={A∈Λ:μ(A)<∞}.

  b. Define a relation ≃\simeq≃ on A\mathcal{A}A by A≃BA \simeq BA≃B if μ(A△B)=0\mu(A \triangle B) = 0μ(A△B)=0. Show that ≃\simeq≃ is an equivalence relation on A\mathcal{A}A.
  c. Let DDD denote the set of all equivalence classes of A\mathcal{A}A. For A∈AA \in \mathcal{A}A∈A, let A˙\dot{A}A˙ denote the equivalence class of AAA in DDD. Now for A˙,B˙∈D\dot{A}, \dot{B} \in DA˙,B˙∈D, define
d(A˙,B˙)=μ(A△B).d(\dot{A}, \dot{B}) = \mu(A \triangle B).d(A˙,B˙)=μ(A△B).
Show that ddd is well defined and that (D,d)(D, d)(D,d) is a complete metric space. (For this part, see also Exercise [3] of Section [31].)

Solution.

Note that if A,B,A, B,A,B, and CCC are three arbitrary sets, then
AΔC⊆(AΔB)∪(BΔC).A \Delta C \subseteq (A \Delta B) \cup (B \Delta C).AΔC⊆(AΔB)∪(BΔC).

(a) Straightforward. (Note that in actuality A\mathcal{A}A is a ring of sets.)

(b) If A,B,A, B,A,B, and CCC in A\mathcal{A}A satisfy A≃BA \simeq BA≃B and B≃CB \simeq CB≃C, then the relation
μ(AΔC)≤μ((AΔB)∪(BΔC))≤μ(AΔB)+μ(BΔC)=0\mu(A \Delta C) \leq \mu((A \Delta B) \cup (B \Delta C)) \leq \mu(A \Delta B) + \mu(B \Delta C) = 0μ(AΔC)≤μ((AΔB)∪(BΔC))≤μ(AΔB)+μ(BΔC)=0
shows that A≃CA \simeq CA≃C.

(c) If A≃A1A \simeq A_1A≃A1​ and B≃B1B \simeq B_1B≃B1​, then
μ(AΔB)≤μ((AΔA1)∪(A1ΔB1)∪(B1ΔB))≤μ(AΔA1)+μ(A1ΔB1)+μ(B1ΔB)=μ(A1ΔB1).\begin{aligned} \mu(A \Delta B) &\leq \mu((A \Delta A_1) \cup (A_1 \Delta B_1) \cup (B_1 \Delta B)) \\ &\leq \mu(A \Delta A_1) + \mu(A_1 \Delta B_1) + \mu(B_1 \Delta B) = \mu(A_1 \Delta B_1). \end{aligned}μ(AΔB)​≤μ((AΔA1​)∪(A1​ΔB1​)∪(B1​ΔB))≤μ(AΔA1​)+μ(A1​ΔB1​)+μ(B1​ΔB)=μ(A1​ΔB1​).​

Similarly,
μ(A1ΔB1)≤μ(AΔB),\mu(A_1 \Delta B_1) \leq \mu(A \Delta B),μ(A1​ΔB1​)≤μ(AΔB),
and so
μ(AΔB)=μ(A1ΔB1).\mu(A \Delta B) = \mu(A_1 \Delta B_1).μ(AΔB)=μ(A1​ΔB1​).
This shows that
d(A˙,B˙)=μ(AΔB)d(\dot{A}, \dot{B}) = \mu(A \Delta B)d(A˙,B˙)=μ(AΔB)
is well defined.

For the triangle inequality, note that
d(A˙,B˙)=μ(AΔB)≤μ(AΔC)+μ(CΔB)=d(A˙,C˙)+d(C˙,B˙).d(\dot{A}, \dot{B}) = \mu(A \Delta B) \leq \mu(A \Delta C) + \mu(C \Delta B) = d(\dot{A}, \dot{C}) + d(\dot{C}, \dot{B}).d(A˙,B˙)=μ(AΔB)≤μ(AΔC)+μ(CΔB)=d(A˙,C˙)+d(C˙,B˙).
Thus, (D,d)(D, d)(D,d) is a metric space.
What remains to be shown is that (D,d)(D, d)(D,d) is a complete metric space.

To this end, let {A˙n}\{\dot{A}_n\}{A˙n​} be a Cauchy sequence of DDD. By passing to a subsequence, we can assume that
d(A˙n+1,A˙n)=μ(An+1ΔAn)<2−n−1d(\dot{A}_{n+1}, \dot{A}_n) = \mu(A_{n+1} \Delta A_n) < 2^{-n-1}d(A˙n+1​,A˙n​)=μ(An+1​ΔAn​)<2−n−1
holds for each nnn. Set
A=⋂k=1∞⋃i=k∞Ai∈Λ.A = \bigcap_{k=1}^{\infty} \bigcup_{i=k}^{\infty} A_i \in \Lambda.A=k=1⋂∞​i=k⋃∞​Ai​∈Λ.
Now, let nnn be fixed and note that
A⊆⋃j=n∞Aj=An∪(⋃i=n∞(Ai+1∖Ai))A \subseteq \bigcup_{j=n}^{\infty} A_j = A_n \cup \left( \bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} (A_{i+1} \setminus A_i) \right)A⊆j=n⋃∞​Aj​=An​∪(i=n⋃∞​(Ai+1​∖Ai​))
holds. Thus,
μ(A)≤μ(An)+∑i=n∞μ(Ai+1∖Ai)<μ(An)+2−n<∞,\mu(A) \leq \mu(A_n) + \sum_{i=n}^{\infty} \mu(A_{i+1} \setminus A_i) < \mu(A_n) + 2^{-n} < \infty,μ(A)≤μ(An​)+i=n∑∞​μ(Ai+1​∖Ai​)<μ(An​)+2−n<∞,
and so A˙∈D\dot{A} \in DA˙∈D. Moreover, we have
μ(A∖An)≤μ(⋃i=n∞(Ai+1∖Ai))≤∑i=n∞μ(Ai+1∖Ai)<2−n.\mu(A \setminus A_n) \leq \mu\left( \bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} (A_{i+1} \setminus A_i) \right) \leq \sum_{i=n}^{\infty} \mu(A_{i+1} \setminus A_i) < 2^{-n}.μ(A∖An​)≤μ(i=n⋃∞​(Ai+1​∖Ai​))≤i=n∑∞​μ(Ai+1​∖Ai​)<2−n.

On the other hand, if x∈An∖Ax \in A_n \setminus Ax∈An​∖A, then x∈Anx \in A_nx∈An​ and x∉Ax \notin Ax∈/A.
Consequently, there exists some k≥nk \geq nk≥n with x∉Aix \notin A_ix∈/Ai​ for each i≥ki \geq ki≥k.

An∖A⊆⋃i=n∞(Ai∖Ai+1),A_n \setminus A \subseteq \bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} (A_i \setminus A_{i+1}),An​∖A⊆i=n⋃∞​(Ai​∖Ai+1​),
and so
μ(An∖A)≤∑i=n∞μ(Ai∖Ai+1)<2−n\mu(A_n \setminus A) \leq \sum_{i=n}^{\infty} \mu(A_i \setminus A_{i+1}) < 2^{-n}μ(An​∖A)≤i=n∑∞​μ(Ai​∖Ai+1​)<2−n
also holds. Therefore,
d(A˙n,A˙)=μ(AnΔA)=μ(An∖A)+μ(A∖An)<21−nd(\dot{A}_n, \dot{A}) = \mu(A_n \Delta A) = \mu(A_n \setminus A) + \mu(A \setminus A_n) < 2^{1-n}d(A˙n​,A˙)=μ(An​ΔA)=μ(An​∖A)+μ(A∖An​)<21−n
holds for each nnn.
This shows that lim⁡d(A˙n,A˙)=0\lim d(\dot{A}_n, \dot{A}) = 0limd(A˙n​,A˙)=0, and so (D,d)(D, d)(D,d) is a complete metric space.
(For an alternate proof of this part, see Problem 31.3.)

15. THE OUTER MEASURE GENERATED BY A MEASURE

Throughout this section, (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) will be a fixed measure space. Our main objective here is to study the remarkable properties of the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ generated by μ\muμ. Among other results, we shall establish that the σ\sigmaσ-algebra of all μ∗\mu^*μ∗-measurable subsets of XXX contains the members of the semiring S\mathcal{S}S. It will then become apparent that the semirings are the smallest collections of sets on which a “reasonable measure theory” can be built.

Recall from the previous section that the outer measure μ∗:P(X)→[0,∞]\mu^* : \mathcal{P}(X) \to [0, \infty]μ∗:P(X)→[0,∞] generated by μ\muμ is defined by
μ∗(A)=inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An} is a sequence of S with A⊆⋃n=1∞An}.\mu^*(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \text{ is a sequence of } \mathcal{S} \text{ with } A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n \right\}.μ∗(A)=inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​} is a sequence of S with A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}.

If there is no sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of S\mathcal{S}S such that A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​, then we let μ∗(A)=∞\mu^*(A) = \inftyμ∗(A)=∞. That is, we adhere to the convention inf⁡∅=∞\inf \emptyset = \inftyinf∅=∞. Recall also that (as we saw in Theorem 14.9) the set function μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is indeed an outer measure.

In general, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ need not be a measure, since it may fail to be σ\sigmaσ-additive on P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X). However, if μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is restricted to the σ\sigmaσ-algebra of all measurable sets, then we already know (by Theorem 14.7) that it is σ\sigmaσ-additive.

The next theorem shows that the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is in fact an extension of μ\muμ from S\mathcal{S}S to P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X).

Theorem 15.1. The outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is an extension of μ\muμ. That is, if A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S, then μ∗(A)=μ(A)\mu^*(A) = \mu(A)μ∗(A)=μ(A) holds.

Proof

Let A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S. From Theorem 14.9, we already know that μ∗(A)≤μ(A)\mu^*(A) \leq \mu(A)μ∗(A)≤μ(A). Now, let {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S with A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​. By the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity of μ\muμ (Theorem 13.8), μ(A)≤∑n=1∞μ(An)\mu(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n)μ(A)≤∑n=1∞​μ(An​) holds, from which it follows immediately that μ(A)≤μ∗(A)\mu(A) \leq \mu^*(A)μ(A)≤μ∗(A). Hence, μ∗(A)=μ(A)\mu^*(A) = \mu(A)μ∗(A)=μ(A). ■\blacksquare■

Since the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ generated by a measure is an extension of μ\muμ, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is also called the Carathéodory extension of μ\muμ. From now on the expression “the outer measure of a set AAA” will also be referred to as “the measure of AAA.”

The measurable sets of an outer measure generated by a measure have a number of useful characterizations. Some of them are included in the next theorem.

Theorem 15.2. Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a measure space, and let μ∗\mu^*μ∗ be the outer measure generated by μ\muμ. For a subset EEE of XXX, the following statements are equivalent:

  1. EEE is measurable with respect to μ∗\mu^*μ∗.
  2. μ(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)\mu(A) = \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c)μ(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec) holds for all A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S with μ(A)<∞\mu(A) < \inftyμ(A)<∞.
  3. μ(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)\mu(A) \geq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c)μ(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec) holds for all A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S with μ(A)<∞\mu(A) < \inftyμ(A)<∞.
  4. μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)\mu^*(A) \geq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c)μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec) holds for all A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X.
Proof

(1) ⟹ (2) and (2) ⟹ (3) are obvious.

(3) ⟹ (4) Let A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. If μ∗(A)=∞\mu^*(A) = \inftyμ∗(A)=∞, then (4) holds trivially. Hence, assume μ∗(A)<∞\mu^*(A) < \inftyμ∗(A)<∞. Let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Choose a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of S\mathcal{S}S with A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​ and ∑n=1∞μ(An)<μ∗(A)+ϵ\sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) < \mu^*(A) + \epsilon∑n=1∞​μ(An​)<μ∗(A)+ϵ. It follows that μ(An)<∞\mu(A_n) < \inftyμ(An​)<∞ for each nnn, and so μ∗(An∩E)+μ∗(An∩Ec)≤μ(An)\mu^*(A_n \cap E) + \mu^*(A_n \cap E^c) \leq \mu(A_n)μ∗(An​∩E)+μ∗(An​∩Ec)≤μ(An​) holds for each nnn, by our hypothesis. Therefore,
μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)≤μ∗([⋃n=1∞An]∩E)+μ∗([⋃n=1∞An]∩Ec)\mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c) \leq \mu^*\left( \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n \right] \cap E \right) + \mu^*\left( \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n \right] \cap E^c \right)μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)≤μ∗([n=1⋃∞​An​]∩E)+μ∗([n=1⋃∞​An​]∩Ec)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(An∩E)+∑n=1∞μ∗(An∩Ec)\leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu^*(A_n \cap E) + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu^*(A_n \cap E^c)≤n=1∑∞​μ∗(An​∩E)+n=1∑∞​μ∗(An​∩Ec)=∑n=1∞[μ∗(An∩E)+μ∗(An∩Ec)]= \sum_{n=1}^\infty [\mu^*(A_n \cap E) + \mu^*(A_n \cap E^c)]=n=1∑∞​[μ∗(An​∩E)+μ∗(An​∩Ec)]≤∑n=1∞μ(An)≤μ∗(A)+ϵ\leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) \leq \mu^*(A) + \epsilon≤n=1∑∞​μ(An​)≤μ∗(A)+ϵfor all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, so that
μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec).\mu^*(A) \geq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c).μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec).(4) ⟹ (1) By the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity property of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, we have μ∗(A)≤μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec),\mu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c),μ∗(A)≤μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec), hence μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)for all A⊆X.\mu^*(A) = \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c) \quad \text{for all } A \subseteq X.μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)for all A⊆X. Thus, EEE is measurable. ■\blacksquare■

A subset EEE of a measure space (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) will be called measurable (more precisely μ\muμ-measurable) if EEE is measurable with respect to the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ generated by μ\muμ.

Theorem 15.3. Every member of S\mathcal{S}S is measurable. That is, S⊆Λ\mathcal{S} \subseteq \LambdaS⊆Λ.

Proof

Let E∈SE \in \mathcal{S}E∈S. We have to show that EEE is a measurable set. If A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S, then there exist pairwise disjoint sets B1,…,BnB_1, \ldots, B_nB1​,…,Bn​ of S\mathcal{S}S such that
A∩Ec=A∖E=⋃i=1nBi.A \cap E^c = A \setminus E = \bigcup_{i=1}^n B_i.A∩Ec=A∖E=i=1⋃n​Bi​.
Note that A∩E,B1,…,BnA \cap E, B_1, \ldots, B_nA∩E,B1​,…,Bn​ is a disjoint collection of members of S\mathcal{S}S such that
A=(A∩E)∪B1∪⋯∪Bn.A = (A \cap E) \cup B_1 \cup \cdots \cup B_n.A=(A∩E)∪B1​∪⋯∪Bn​.
By the σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity property of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, we obtain
μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)≤μ∗(A∩E)+∑i=1nμ∗(Bi)=μ(A∩E)+∑i=1nμ(Bi)=μ(A),\mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c) \leq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \sum_{i=1}^n \mu^*(B_i) = \mu(A \cap E) + \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(B_i) = \mu(A),μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)≤μ∗(A∩E)+i=1∑n​μ∗(Bi​)=μ(A∩E)+i=1∑n​μ(Bi​)=μ(A),
where the last two equalities hold true by virtue of Theorem 15.1 and the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ on S\mathcal{S}S. By Theorem 15.2, EEE is measurable, and so S⊆Λ\mathcal{S} \subseteq \LambdaS⊆Λ. ■\blacksquare■

Let us write An↑AA_n \uparrow AAn​↑A to mean that the sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of subsets of XXX satisfies An⊆An+1A_n \subseteq A_{n+1}An​⊆An+1​ for each nnn and A=⋃n=1∞AnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA=⋃n=1∞​An​. Similarly, An↓AA_n \downarrow AAn​↓A means An+1⊆AnA_{n+1} \subseteq A_nAn+1​⊆An​ for each nnn and A=⋂n=1∞AnA = \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA=⋂n=1∞​An​.

Theorem 15.4. For a measure space (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) and a sequence of measurable sets {En}\{E_n\}{En​}, the following statements hold:

  1. If En↑EE_n \uparrow EEn​↑E, then μ∗(En)↑μ∗(E)\mu^*(E_n) \uparrow \mu^*(E)μ∗(En​)↑μ∗(E).
  2. If En↓EE_n \downarrow EEn​↓E and μ∗(Ek)<∞\mu^*(E_k) < \inftyμ∗(Ek​)<∞ holds for some kkk, then μ∗(En)↓μ∗(E)\mu^*(E_n) \downarrow \mu^*(E)μ∗(En​)↓μ∗(E).
Proof

(1) Let B1=E1B_1 = E_1B1​=E1​ and Bn=En∖En−1B_n = E_n \setminus E_{n-1}Bn​=En​∖En−1​ for n≥2n \geq 2n≥2. Then each BnB_nBn​ is measurable, and Bi∩Bj=∅B_i \cap B_j = \emptysetBi​∩Bj​=∅ if i≠ji \ne ji=j. Also,
En=⋃i=1nBiandE=⋃i=1∞Bi.E_n = \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} B_i \quad \text{and} \quad E = \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} B_i.En​=i=1⋃n​Bi​andE=i=1⋃∞​Bi​.
Hence, by Theorem 14.7 we have
μ∗(E)=∑i=1∞μ∗(Bi)=lim⁡n→∞∑i=1nμ∗(Bi).\mu^*(E) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(B_i) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu^*(B_i).μ∗(E)=i=1∑∞​μ∗(Bi​)=n→∞lim​i=1∑n​μ∗(Bi​).
But μ∗(En)=∑i=1nμ∗(Bi)\mu^*(E_n) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu^*(B_i)μ∗(En​)=∑i=1n​μ∗(Bi​), and thus, μ∗(En)↑μ∗(E)\mu^*(E_n) \uparrow \mu^*(E)μ∗(En​)↑μ∗(E) holds.
(2) Observe that without loss of generality we can assume μ∗(E1)<∞\mu^*(E_1) < \inftyμ∗(E1​)<∞. Now,
E1∖En↑E1∖E,E_1 \setminus E_n \uparrow E_1 \setminus E,E1​∖En​↑E1​∖E,
and so, by part (1),
lim⁡μ∗(E1∖En)=μ∗(E1∖E).\lim \mu^*(E_1 \setminus E_n) = \mu^*(E_1 \setminus E).limμ∗(E1​∖En​)=μ∗(E1​∖E).
Applying Theorem 14.8, we get
lim⁡[μ∗(E1)−μ∗(En)]=μ∗(E1)−μ∗(E),\lim [\mu^*(E_1) - \mu^*(E_n)] = \mu^*(E_1) - \mu^*(E),lim[μ∗(E1​)−μ∗(En​)]=μ∗(E1​)−μ∗(E),
from which it follows that
μ∗(En)↓μ∗(E).■\mu^*(E_n) \downarrow \mu^*(E). \quad \blacksquareμ∗(En​)↓μ∗(E).■

As an application of the results obtained so far, we shall show that the Lebesgue outer measure on R\mathbb{R}R generalizes the ordinary concept of length. Remember that the Lebesgue measure λ\lambdaλ is the measure defined on the semiring S={[a,b):a,b∈R}\mathcal{S} = \{ [a, b) : a, b \in \mathbb{R} \}S={[a,b):a,b∈R} by λ([a,b))=b−a\lambda([a, b)) = b - aλ([a,b))=b−a for all a≤ba \leq ba≤b. It is a custom to call (and we shall do so) the outer measure λ∗\lambda^*λ∗ generated by λ\lambdaλ the Lebesgue measure on R\mathbb{R}R.

A subset III of R\mathbb{R}R is called an interval if for every x,y∈Ix, y \in Ix,y∈I with x<yx < yx<y, we have [x,y]⊆I[x, y] \subseteq I[x,y]⊆I. If III has any one of the forms [a,b)[a, b)[a,b), [a,b][a, b][a,b], (a,b](a, b](a,b], or (a,b)(a, b)(a,b) with −∞<a<b<∞-\infty < a < b < \infty−∞<a<b<∞, then III is called a bounded interval, and its length is defined by ∣I∣=b−a|I| = b - a∣I∣=b−a. If III is unbounded, then its length is said to be infinite, which is written ∣I∣=∞|I| = \infty∣I∣=∞.

Example 15.5. Every interval III of R\mathbb{R}R is Lebesgue measurable and λ∗(I)=∣I∣\lambda^*(I) = |I|λ∗(I)=∣I∣.

Proof

To see this, note that by Theorem 15.3 every set of the form [a,b)[a, b)[a,b) with −∞<a<b<∞-\infty < a < b < \infty−∞<a<b<∞ is Lebesgue measurable. Moreover, Theorem 15.1 shows that
λ∗([a,b))=λ([a,b))=b−a=∣[a,b)∣.\lambda^*([a, b)) = \lambda([a, b)) = b - a = |[a, b)|.λ∗([a,b))=λ([a,b))=b−a=∣[a,b)∣.

We shall prove two more cases and leave the rest for the reader. Our first case is a bounded interval of the form I=[a,b]I = [a, b]I=[a,b]. Let En=[a,b+1n)E_n = [a, b + \frac{1}{n})En​=[a,b+n1​) for each nnn. Then each EnE_nEn​ is Lebesgue measurable, and En↓IE_n \downarrow IEn​↓I holds. Hence, III is Lebesgue measurable, and by Theorem 15.4(2), we get
λ∗(I)=lim⁡n→∞λ∗([a,b+1n))=lim⁡n→∞(b+1n−a)=b−a=∣I∣.\lambda^*(I) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \lambda^*\left([a, b + \frac{1}{n})\right) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left(b + \frac{1}{n} - a\right) = b - a = |I|.λ∗(I)=n→∞lim​λ∗([a,b+n1​))=n→∞lim​(b+n1​−a)=b−a=∣I∣.

The second case is an interval of the form I=[a,∞)I = [a, \infty)I=[a,∞). Put Fn=[a,a+n)F_n = [a, a + n)Fn​=[a,a+n) for each nnn, and note that Fn↑IF_n \uparrow IFn​↑I holds. Thus, III is Lebesgue measurable, and by Theorem 15.4(1) we have
λ∗(I)=lim⁡n→∞λ∗([a,a+n))=lim⁡n→∞n=∞=∣I∣,\lambda^*(I) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \lambda^*([a, a + n)) = \lim_{n \to \infty} n = \infty = |I|,λ∗(I)=n→∞lim​λ∗([a,a+n))=n→∞lim​n=∞=∣I∣,
as desired.■\blacksquare■

Two important classes of measure spaces are inrtoduces next.

Definition 15.6. A measure space (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is said to be:

  1. finite, if μ∗(X)<∞\mu^*(X) < \inftyμ∗(X)<∞, and
  2. σ\sigmaσ-finite, if there exists a sequence {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​} of subsets of XXX such that
    X=⋃n=1∞Xnandμ∗(Xn)<∞ for each n.X = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} X_n \quad \text{and} \quad \mu^*(X_n) < \infty \text{ for each } n.X=n=1⋃∞​Xn​andμ∗(Xn​)<∞ for each n.

Clearly, every finite measure space is σ\sigmaσ-finite. We also have the following:

Lemma 15.7. A measure space (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is σ\sigmaσ-finite if and only if there exists a disjoint sequence {Yn}\{Y_n\}{Yn​} of S\mathcal{S}S such that
X=⋃n=1∞Ynandμ(Yn)<∞ for each n.X = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} Y_n \quad \text{and} \quad \mu(Y_n) < \infty \text{ for each } n.X=n=1⋃∞​Yn​andμ(Yn​)<∞ for each n.

Proof

To see the “only if” part, assume that (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is σ\sigmaσ-finite. Choose subsets X1,X2,…X_1, X_2, \ldotsX1​,X2​,… of XXX such that
X=⋃i=1∞Xiandμ∗(Xi)<∞ for each i.X = \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} X_i \quad \text{and} \quad \mu^*(X_i) < \infty \text{ for each } i.X=i=1⋃∞​Xi​andμ∗(Xi​)<∞ for each i.
Now, for each iii, choose a sequence {Ani}⊂S\{A_n^i\} \subset \mathcal{S}{Ani​}⊂S such that
Xi⊆⋃n=1∞Aniand∑n=1∞μ(Ani)<μ∗(Xi)+1.X_i \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^i \quad \text{and} \quad \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^i) < \mu^*(X_i) + 1.Xi​⊆n=1⋃∞​Ani​andn=1∑∞​μ(Ani​)<μ∗(Xi​)+1.
Then Ani∈SA_n^i \in \mathcal{S}Ani​∈S, μ(Ani)<∞\mu(A_n^i) < \inftyμ(Ani​)<∞ for each nnn and iii, and
X=⋃i=1∞⋃n=1∞Ani.X = \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^i.X=i=1⋃∞​n=1⋃∞​Ani​.
Now, by applying Theorem 12.2 and Lemma 12.3, our claim can be established. ■\blacksquare■

The measurable sets of a finite measure space have a simple characterization.

Theorem 15.8. Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a finite measure space, and let EEE be a subset of XXX. Then EEE is measurable if and only if
μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X).\mu^*(E) + \mu^*(E^c) = \mu^*(X).μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X).

Proof

Clearly, if EEE is measurable, then μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X)\mu^*(E) + \mu^*(E^c) = \mu^*(X)μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X) holds.
For the converse, assume that μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X)\mu^*(E) + \mu^*(E^c) = \mu^*(X)μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(X) holds. Let A∈SA \in \mathcal{S}A∈S. The measurability of AAA applied to EEE and EcE^cEc gives
μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac),\mu^*(E) = \mu^*(E \cap A) + \mu^*(E \cap A^c),μ∗(E)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac),
μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac).\mu^*(E^c) = \mu^*(E^c \cap A) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A^c).μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac).

By adding the last two equalities, we get
μ∗(X)=μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac)\mu^*(X) = \mu^*(E) + \mu^*(E^c) = \mu^*(E \cap A) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A) + \mu^*(E \cap A^c) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A^c)μ∗(X)=μ∗(E)+μ∗(Ec)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac)
≥μ∗(A)+μ∗(Ac)≥μ∗(A∪Ac)=μ∗(X).\geq \mu^*(A) + \mu^*(A^c) \geq \mu^*(A \cup A^c) = \mu^*(X).≥μ∗(A)+μ∗(Ac)≥μ∗(A∪Ac)=μ∗(X).

Therefore,
μ∗(A)+μ∗(Ac)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac).\mu^*(A) + \mu^*(A^c) = \mu^*(E \cap A) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A) + \mu^*(E \cap A^c) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A^c).μ∗(A)+μ∗(Ac)=μ∗(E∩A)+μ∗(Ec∩A)+μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac).

In view of μ∗(Ac)≤μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac)\mu^*(A^c) \leq \mu^*(E \cap A^c) + \mu^*(E^c \cap A^c)μ∗(Ac)≤μ∗(E∩Ac)+μ∗(Ec∩Ac) and μ∗(X)<∞\mu^*(X) < \inftyμ∗(X)<∞, the last equality gives
μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec).\mu^*(A) \geq \mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c).μ∗(A)≥μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec).

This last inequality is the one required by Theorem 15.2 for the measurability of EEE, and the proof of the theorem is complete.■\blacksquare■

Notice that Theorem 15.3 combined with Theorem 12.2 shows that in the definition of the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗, we can consider only disjoint sequences of S\mathcal{S}S. That is, we have the following useful result:

Lemma 15.9. If (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a measure space, thenμ∗(A)=inf⁡{∑n=1∞μ(An):{An}⊆S,{An} disjoint, and A⊆⋃n=1∞An}\mu^*(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) : \{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}, \{A_n\} \text{ disjoint, and } A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right\}μ∗(A)=inf{n=1∑∞​μ(An​):{An​}⊆S,{An​} disjoint, and A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​}=inf⁡{μ∗(B):B is a σ-set and A⊆B}= \inf \{ \mu^*(B) : B \text{ is a } \sigma\text{-set and } A \subseteq B \}=inf{μ∗(B):B is a σ-set and A⊆B}holds true for every subset AAA of XXX (with inf⁡∅=∞\inf \emptyset = \inftyinf∅=∞).

Theorem 15.10.
Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure space, Σ\SigmaΣ a semiring of sets such that S⊆Σ⊆Λ\mathcal{S} \subseteq \Sigma \subseteq \LambdaS⊆Σ⊆Λ, and ν\nuν a measure on Σ\SigmaΣ. If ν=μ\nu = \muν=μ on S\mathcal{S}S, then ν=μ∗\nu = \mu^*ν=μ∗ on Σ\SigmaΣ.
In this case, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is the one and only extension of μ\muμ to a measure on Λ\LambdaΛ.

Proof

Let ν∗\nu^*ν∗ be the outer measure generated by (X,Σ,ν)(X, \Sigma, \nu)(X,Σ,ν). Now, let A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X, and let {An}\{A_n\}{An​} be a sequence of S\mathcal{S}S such that A⊆⋃n=1∞AnA \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nA⊆⋃n=1∞​An​. Since μ\muμ and ν\nuν agree on S\mathcal{S}S, we have
ν∗(A)≤∑n=1∞ν(An)=∑n=1∞μ(An).\nu^*(A) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(A_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n).ν∗(A)≤n=1∑∞​ν(An​)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​).
This implies ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A)\nu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(A)ν∗(A)≤μ∗(A) for all A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X.

Now, assume that A∈ΣA \in \SigmaA∈Σ satisfies μ∗(A)<∞\mu^*(A) < \inftyμ∗(A)<∞. We shall show that μ∗(A)≤ν(A)\mu^*(A) \leq \nu(A)μ∗(A)≤ν(A), and therefore, ν(A)=μ∗(A)\nu(A) = \mu^*(A)ν(A)=μ∗(A) will be established in this case. To this end, let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Choose a disjoint sequence {An}⊆S\{A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{S}{An​}⊆S such that
A⊆⋃n=1∞An,∑n=1∞μ(An)<μ∗(A)+ϵ.A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n, \quad \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) < \mu^*(A) + \epsilon.A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​,n=1∑∞​μ(An​)<μ∗(A)+ϵ.
Put B=⋃n=1∞AnB = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_nB=⋃n=1∞​An​, and note that B∈ΛμB \in \Lambda_{\mu}B∈Λμ​, B∈ΛνB \in \Lambda_{\nu}B∈Λν​, and μ∗(B)≤μ∗(A)+ϵ\mu^*(B) \leq \mu^*(A) + \epsilonμ∗(B)≤μ∗(A)+ϵ. Now, observe that
ν∗(B∖A)≤μ∗(B∖A)=μ∗(B)−μ∗(A)<ϵ.\nu^*(B \setminus A) \leq \mu^*(B \setminus A) = \mu^*(B) - \mu^*(A) < \epsilon.ν∗(B∖A)≤μ∗(B∖A)=μ∗(B)−μ∗(A)<ϵ.
Therefore,
μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)=∑n=1∞μ(An)=∑n=1∞ν(An)=ν∗(B)\mu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(B) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \nu(A_n) = \nu^*(B)μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)=n=1∑∞​μ(An​)=n=1∑∞​ν(An​)=ν∗(B)
=ν∗(A)+ν∗(B∖A)<ν(A)+ϵ= \nu^*(A) + \nu^*(B \setminus A) < \nu(A) + \epsilon=ν∗(A)+ν∗(B∖A)<ν(A)+ϵ
for all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Hence, μ∗(A)≤ν(A)\mu^*(A) \leq \nu(A)μ∗(A)≤ν(A).
For the general case, let {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​} be a disjoint sequence of S\mathcal{S}S covering XXX such that
μ∗(Xn)<∞for all n.\mu^*(X_n) < \infty \quad \text{for all } n.μ∗(Xn​)<∞for all n.
Now, if A∈ΣA \in \SigmaA∈Σ, then by the above,
ν(Xn∩A)=μ∗(Xn∩A)\nu(X_n \cap A) = \mu^*(X_n \cap A)ν(Xn​∩A)=μ∗(Xn​∩A)
holds for all nnn, and so
μ∗(A)=μ∗(⋃n=1∞[Xn∩A])=∑n=1∞μ∗(Xn∩A)\mu^*(A) = \mu^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [X_n \cap A] \right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu^*(X_n \cap A)μ∗(A)=μ∗(n=1⋃∞​[Xn​∩A])=n=1∑∞​μ∗(Xn​∩A)
=∑n=1∞ν(Xn∩A)=ν∗(⋃n=1∞[Xn∩A])=ν(A),= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \nu(X_n \cap A) = \nu^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [X_n \cap A] \right) = \nu(A),=n=1∑∞​ν(Xn​∩A)=ν∗(n=1⋃∞​[Xn​∩A])=ν(A),
and the proof is finished. ■\blacksquare■

A subset AAA of a measure space (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is said to be σ\sigmaσ-finite if there exists a sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} of S\mathcal{S}S such that
A⊆⋃n=1∞Anandμ(An)<∞ for each n.A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \quad \text{and} \quad \mu(A_n) < \infty \text{ for each } n.A⊆n=1⋃∞​An​andμ(An​)<∞ for each n.
Clearly, the sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​} can be chosen to be disjoint.

Repeating verbatim the proof of the last theorem, we can establish the following:

  • Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a measure space, Σ\SigmaΣ be a semiring of subsets of XXX such that S⊆Σ⊆Λ\mathcal{S} \subseteq \Sigma \subseteq \LambdaS⊆Σ⊆Λ, and ν\nuν be a measure on Σ\SigmaΣ. If ν=μ\nu = \muν=μ on S\mathcal{S}S, then
    ν(A)=μ∗(A) holds for every σ-finite set of Σ.\nu(A) = \mu^*(A) \text{ holds for every } \sigma\text{-finite set of } \Sigma.ν(A)=μ∗(A) holds for every σ-finite set of Σ.

It should be noted that the hypothesis of σ\sigmaσ-finiteness in Theorem 15.10 cannot be dropped. As an example, take X=RX = \mathbb{R}X=R,
S={[a,b):a,b∈R},\mathcal{S} = \{[a, b): a, b \in \mathbb{R}\},S={[a,b):a,b∈R},
and define μ:S→[0,∞]\mu : \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] by
μ(∅)=0andμ([a,b))=∞ if a<b.\mu(\emptyset) = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad \mu([a, b)) = \infty \text{ if } a < b.μ(∅)=0andμ([a,b))=∞ if a<b.
Then (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a measure space that is not σ\sigmaσ-finite. Moreover,
Λ=P(X)andμ∗(A)=∞ for every nonempty subset A of X.\Lambda = \mathcal{P}(X) \quad \text{and} \quad \mu^*(A) = \infty \text{ for every nonempty subset } A \text{ of } X.Λ=P(X)andμ∗(A)=∞ for every nonempty subset A of X.
It is easy to see now that the counting measure (see Example 13.3) is an extension of μ\muμ to Λ\LambdaΛ that is different from μ∗\mu^*μ∗.

We continue with an approximation property of an arbitrary set by a measurable set.

Theorem 15.11.
Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a measure space. If AAA is a subset of XXX, then there exists a measurable set EEE such that
A⊆Eandμ∗(E)=μ∗(A).A \subseteq E \quad \text{and} \quad \mu^*(E) = \mu^*(A).A⊆Eandμ∗(E)=μ∗(A).
In particular, if S\mathcal{S}S is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, then for each A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X there exists some E∈SE \in \mathcal{S}E∈S with A⊆EA \subseteq EA⊆E and μ∗(E)=μ∗(A)\mu^*(E) = \mu^*(A)μ∗(E)=μ∗(A).

Proof

Let A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. If μ∗(A)=∞\mu^*(A) = \inftyμ∗(A)=∞, then the measurable set E=XE = XE=X satisfies μ∗(E)=μ∗(A)\mu^*(E) = \mu^*(A)μ∗(E)=μ∗(A). So, assume μ∗(A)<∞\mu^*(A) < \inftyμ∗(A)<∞.

For each iii, choose a sequence {Ani}\{A_n^i\}{Ani​} of the semiring S\mathcal{S}S such that
A⊆⋃n=1∞Aniand∑n=1∞μ(Ani)<μ∗(A)+1i,A \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^i \quad \text{and} \quad \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^i) < \mu^*(A) + \frac{1}{i},A⊆n=1⋃∞​Ani​andn=1∑∞​μ(Ani​)<μ∗(A)+i1​,
and let Ei=⋃n=1∞AniE_i = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n^iEi​=⋃n=1∞​Ani​. Then each EiE_iEi​ is a measurable set such that A⊆EiA \subseteq E_iA⊆Ei​. Put
E=⋂i=1∞Ei.E = \bigcap_{i=1}^{\infty} E_i.E=i=1⋂∞​Ei​.
Then A⊆EA \subseteq EA⊆E, and EEE is measurable (and, of course, E∈SE \in \mathcal{S}E∈S if S\mathcal{S}S is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra). Also,
μ∗(A)≤μ∗(E)≤μ∗(Ei)≤∑n=1∞μ(Ani)<μ∗(A)+1i\mu^*(A) \leq \mu^*(E) \leq \mu^*(E_i) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu(A_n^i) < \mu^*(A) + \frac{1}{i}μ∗(A)≤μ∗(E)≤μ∗(Ei​)≤n=1∑∞​μ(Ani​)<μ∗(A)+i1​
for each iii, implies
μ∗(E)=μ∗(A).■\mu^*(E) = \mu^*(A). \quad \blacksquareμ∗(E)=μ∗(A).■

If AAA is a subset of XXX, then any measurable set EEE satisfying
A⊆Eandμ∗(E)=μ∗(A)A \subseteq E \quad \text{and} \quad \mu^*(E) = \mu^*(A)A⊆Eandμ∗(E)=μ∗(A)
is called by many authors a measurable cover of AAA.

Is every set a measurable set? Of course, the answer is no. It is easy to construct examples where not every set is measurable. Here is a simple example.

Example 15.12.
Let X={1,2,3}X = \{1, 2, 3\}X={1,2,3} and
S={∅,{3},{1,2},X};\mathcal{S} = \{\emptyset, \{3\}, \{1,2\}, X\};S={∅,{3},{1,2},X};
clearly S\mathcal{S}S is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra. It should be easy to check that the set function
μ:S→[0,∞)\mu : \mathcal{S} \rightarrow [0, \infty)μ:S→[0,∞)
defined by
μ(∅)=0,μ({3})=μ({1,2})=1,andμ(X)=2\mu(\emptyset) = 0, \quad \mu(\{3\}) = \mu(\{1, 2\}) = 1, \quad \text{and} \quad \mu(X) = 2μ(∅)=0,μ({3})=μ({1,2})=1,andμ(X)=2
is a measure.

We claim that the set E={1}E = \{1\}E={1} is not measurable. To see this, note first that
μ∗({1})=μ∗({2})=μ∗({1,2})=1.\mu^*(\{1\}) = \mu^*(\{2\}) = \mu^*(\{1, 2\}) = 1.μ∗({1})=μ∗({2})=μ∗({1,2})=1.
Now if A={1,2}A = \{1, 2\}A={1,2}, then
μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)=μ∗({1})+μ∗({2})=1+1>1=μ∗(A),\mu^*(A \cap E) + \mu^*(A \cap E^c) = \mu^*(\{1\}) + \mu^*(\{2\}) = 1 + 1 > 1 = \mu^*(A),μ∗(A∩E)+μ∗(A∩Ec)=μ∗({1})+μ∗({2})=1+1>1=μ∗(A),
and this shows that EEE is not measurable. ■\blacksquare■

It is considerably harder to demonstrate the existence of a non-Lebesgue measurable subset of the real line. The following classical example of a non-measurable subset of the real is due to G. Vitali.

Example 15.13 (Vitali).
Let λ∗\lambda^*λ∗ be the outer measure generated on R\mathbb{R}R by the Lebesgue measure λ\lambdaλ. We define a relation ≃\simeq≃ on [0,1][0, 1][0,1] by saying that
x≃y  ⟺  x−y is a rational number.x \simeq y \iff x - y \text{ is a rational number}.x≃y⟺x−y is a rational number.
An easy verification shows that ≃\simeq≃ is an equivalence relation on [0,1][0, 1][0,1]. Thus, ≃\simeq≃ partitions [0,1][0, 1][0,1] into equivalence classes. Let E⊆[0,1]E \subseteq [0,1]E⊆[0,1] be a set intersecting each equivalence class at precisely one point. By the axiom of choice such a set exists. We claim that EEE is not Lebesgue measurable.

To see this, assume by way of contradiction that EEE is Lebesgue measurable. Let r1,r2,…r_1, r_2, \dotsr1​,r2​,… be an enumeration of the rational numbers in [−1,1][-1, 1][−1,1]. For each nnn, define
En={rn+x:x∈E}=rn+E,E_n = \{r_n + x : x \in E\} = r_n + E,En​={rn​+x:x∈E}=rn​+E,
and note that each EnE_nEn​ is Lebesgue measurable. It is not difficult to see that En∩Em=∅E_n \cap E_m = \emptysetEn​∩Em​=∅ for n≠mn \neq mn=m, and that (since λ∗\lambda^*λ∗ is translation invariant)
λ∗(En)=λ∗(E)for all n.\lambda^*(E_n) = \lambda^*(E) \quad \text{for all } n.λ∗(En​)=λ∗(E)for all n.
Moreover,
[0,1]⊆⋃n=1∞En⊆[−1,2].[0, 1] \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \subseteq [-1, 2].[0,1]⊆n=1⋃∞​En​⊆[−1,2].
By the σ\sigmaσ-additivity of λ∗\lambda^*λ∗, we get
λ∗(⋃n=1∞En)=∑n=1∞λ∗(En)=lim⁡n→∞[nλ∗(E)]≤λ∗([−1,2])=3.\lambda^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda^*(E_n) = \lim_{n \to \infty} [n \lambda^*(E)] \leq \lambda^*([-1, 2]) = 3.λ∗(n=1⋃∞​En​)=n=1∑∞​λ∗(En​)=n→∞lim​[nλ∗(E)]≤λ∗([−1,2])=3.

This implies λ∗(E)=0\lambda^*(E) = 0λ∗(E)=0, and hence
λ∗(⋃n=1∞En)=0.\lambda^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right) = 0.λ∗(n=1⋃∞​En​)=0.
On the other hand,
[0,1]⊆⋃n=1∞En[0, 1] \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n[0,1]⊆n=1⋃∞​En​
shows that
1≤λ∗(⋃n=1∞En),1 \leq \lambda^*\left( \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} E_n \right),1≤λ∗(n=1⋃∞​En​),
which is a contradiction. Therefore,
E cannot be a Lebesgue measurable set.■E \text{ cannot be a Lebesgue measurable set.} \quad \blacksquareE cannot be a Lebesgue measurable set.■

  2. Let (X,S1,μ1)(X, \mathcal{S}_1, \mu_1)(X,S1​,μ1​) and (X,S2,μ2)(X, \mathcal{S}_2, \mu_2)(X,S2​,μ2​) be two measure spaces. Show that μ1\mu_1μ1​ and μ2\mu_2μ2​ generate the same outer measure on XXX if and only if μ1=μ2∗\mu_1 = \mu_2^*μ1​=μ2∗​ on S1\mathcal{S}_1S1​ and μ2=μ1∗\mu_2 = \mu_1^*μ2​=μ1∗​ on S2\mathcal{S}_2S2​ both hold.

  3. Let (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) be a measure space. A measurable set AAA is called an atom if μ∗(A)>0\mu^*(A) > 0μ∗(A)>0 and for every measurable subset EEE of AAA we have either μ∗(E)=0\mu^*(E) = 0μ∗(E)=0 or μ∗(A∖E)=0\mu^*(A \setminus E) = 0μ∗(A∖E)=0. If (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) does not have any atoms, then it is called a nonatomic measure space.
    a. Find the atoms of the measure spaces of Examples 13.3 and 13.4.
    b. Show that the real line with the Lebesgue measure is a nonatomic measure space.

  4. This exercise presents an example of a measure that has infinitely many extensions to a measure on the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by S\mathcal{S}S. Fix a proper nonempty subset AAA of a set XXX (i.e., A≠XA \ne XA=X) and consider the collection of subsets S={∅,A}\mathcal{S} = \{ \emptyset, A \}S={∅,A}.
    a. Show that S\mathcal{S}S is a semiring.
    b. Show that the set function μ ⁣:S→[0,∞]\mu \colon \mathcal{S} \to [0, \infty]μ:S→[0,∞] defined by μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0 and μ(A)=1\mu(A) = 1μ(A)=1 is a measure.
    c. Describe the Carathéodory extension μ∗\mu^*μ∗ of μ\muμ.
    d. Determine the σ\sigmaσ-algebra of measurable sets Λμ\Lambda_\muΛμ​.
    e. Show that μ\muμ has uncountably many extensions to a measure on the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by S\mathcal{S}S. Why doesn’t this contradict Theorem 15.10?

16. MEASURABLE FUNCTIONS

An important role in the theory of integration is played by the so-called almost everywhere relations. If μ\muμ is an outer measure of XXX, then a relation involving the elements of XXX is said to hold almost everywhere (or that it holds for almost all xxx) if the set AAA of all points for which the relation fails to hold is a null set (i.e., μ(A)=0\mu(A) = 0μ(A)=0). For instance, if fff and ggg are real-valued functions defined on XXX, then
f≤gf \leq gf≤g almost everywhere means that
μ({x∈X:f(x)>g(x)})=0.\mu(\{ x \in X : f(x) > g(x) \}) = 0.μ({x∈X:f(x)>g(x)})=0.
Similarly, {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​} converges to fff almost everywhere if there is a set AAA of measure zero such that
lim⁡fn(x)=f(x)for all x∉A.\lim f_n(x) = f(x) \quad \text{for all } x \notin A.limfn​(x)=f(x)for all x∈/A.

If (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a measure space, then by saying that a relation holds almost everywhere (abbreviated a.e.) we mean that the relation holds almost everywhere with respect to the outer measure μ∗\mu^*μ∗ generated by μ\muμ. The basic almost everywhere relations that will be used in this book are summarized below. We assume that (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) is a given measure space and that fff and ggg denote real-valued functions defined on XXX.

  1. f=gf = gf=g a.e. if μ∗({x∈X:f(x)≠g(x)})=0\mu^*(\{ x \in X : f(x) \ne g(x) \}) = 0μ∗({x∈X:f(x)=g(x)})=0.

  2. f≥gf \geq gf≥g a.e. if μ∗({x∈X:f(x)<g(x)})=0\mu^*(\{ x \in X : f(x) < g(x) \}) = 0μ∗({x∈X:f(x)<g(x)})=0.

  3. fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e. if μ∗({x∈X:fn(x)↛f(x)})=0\mu^*(\{ x \in X : f_n(x) \not\to f(x) \}) = 0μ∗({x∈X:fn​(x)→f(x)})=0.

  4. fn↑ff_n \uparrow ffn​↑f a.e. if fn≤fn+1f_n \leq f_{n+1}fn​≤fn+1​ a.e. for all nnn and fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e.

  5. fn↓ff_n \downarrow ffn​↓f a.e. if fn+1≤fnf_{n+1} \leq f_nfn+1​≤fn​ a.e. for all nnn and fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e.

Throughout this section, (X,S,μ)(X, \mathcal{S}, \mu)(X,S,μ) will denote a fixed measure space.

Definition 16.1.
Let f ⁣:X→Rf \colon X \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R be a function. If f−1(O)f^{-1}(\mathcal{O})f−1(O) is a measurable set for every open subset O\mathcal{O}O of R\mathbb{R}R, then fff is called a measurable function.

Every constant function is measurable. Indeed, if f(x)=cf(x) = cf(x)=c for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and O\mathcal{O}O is an open subset of R\mathbb{R}R, then f−1(O)=∅f^{-1}(\mathcal{O}) = \emptysetf−1(O)=∅ if c∉Oc \notin \mathcal{O}c∈/O, and f−1(O)=Xf^{-1}(\mathcal{O}) = Xf−1(O)=X if c∈Oc \in \mathcal{O}c∈O.

Recall that the Borel sets of a topological space are the members of the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the open sets. The first theorem gives a number of useful characterizations of the measurable functions. (This result is a special case of a more general result regarding measurability of functions; see Theorem 20.6.)

Theorem 16.2.
For a function f:X→Rf: X \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R, the following statements are equivalent:

  1. fff is measurable.
  2. f−1((a,b))f^{-1}((a, b))f−1((a,b)) is measurable for each bounded open interval (a,b)(a, b)(a,b) of R\mathbb{R}R.
  3. f−1(C)f^{-1}(C)f−1(C) is measurable for each closed subset CCC of R\mathbb{R}R.
  4. f−1([a,∞))f^{-1}([a, \infty))f−1([a,∞)) is measurable for each a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R.
  5. f−1((−∞,a])f^{-1}((-\infty, a])f−1((−∞,a]) is measurable for each a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R.
  6. f−1(B)f^{-1}(B)f−1(B) is measurable for each Borel subset BBB of R\mathbb{R}R.
Proof

  • (1) ⟹ (2) Obvious.

  • (2) ⟹ (3) It follows from the relation f−1(C)=[f−1(Cc)]cf^{-1}(C) = [f^{-1}(C^c)]^cf−1(C)=[f−1(Cc)]c and the fact that CcC^cCc can be written as a countable union of bounded open intervals.

  • (3) ⟹ (4) Obvious.

  • (4) ⟹ (5) Note first that
    f−1((−∞,a])=[f−1([a,∞))]cf^{-1}((-\infty, a]) = [f^{-1}([a, \infty))]^cf−1((−∞,a])=[f−1([a,∞))]c
    is measurable for each a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R. The result now follows from the identity
    f−1((−∞,a])=⋂n=1∞f−1((−∞,a+1n)).f^{-1}((-\infty, a]) = \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty f^{-1} \left( \left( -\infty, a + \frac{1}{n} \right) \right).f−1((−∞,a])=n=1⋂∞​f−1((−∞,a+n1​)).

  • (5) ⟹ (6) Let A={A⊆R:f−1(A) is measurable}\mathcal{A} = \{ A \subseteq \mathbb{R} : f^{-1}(A) \text{ is measurable} \}A={A⊆R:f−1(A) is measurable}.
    An easy verification shows that A\mathcal{A}A is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra of subsets of R\mathbb{R}R such that (−∞,a](-\infty, a](−∞,a] belongs to A\mathcal{A}A for each a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R by hypothesis.
    It easily follows that A\mathcal{A}A contains the open subsets of R\mathbb{R}R, and hence, it also contains the Borel sets. Thus, f−1(B)f^{-1}(B)f−1(B) is measurable for each Borel subset BBB of R\mathbb{R}R.

  • (6) ⟹ (1) Obvious.

Two functions that are equal almost everywhere are either both measurable or else both nonmeasurable. The details follow.

Theorem 16.3.
If fff is a measurable function and g ⁣:X→Rg \colon X \to \mathbb{R}g:X→R satisfies f=gf = gf=g a.e., then ggg is a measurable function.

Proof

If A={x∈X:f(x)≠g(x)}A = \{ x \in X : f(x) \ne g(x) \}A={x∈X:f(x)=g(x)}, then from our hypothesis μ∗(A)=0\mu^*(A) = 0μ∗(A)=0, and so, AAA is measurable. Now, let O\mathcal{O}O be an open subset of R\mathbb{R}R. Since fff is a measurable function, f−1(O)f^{-1}(\mathcal{O})f−1(O) is measurable, and hence,
Ac∩g−1(O)=Ac∩f−1(O)A^c \cap g^{-1}(\mathcal{O}) = A^c \cap f^{-1}(\mathcal{O})Ac∩g−1(O)=Ac∩f−1(O)
is a measurable set. Also, since A∩g−1(O)A \cap g^{-1}(\mathcal{O})A∩g−1(O) has outer measure zero, it is measurable. Hence,
g−1(O)=[A∩g−1(O)]∪[Ac∩g−1(O)]g^{-1}(\mathcal{O}) = [A \cap g^{-1}(\mathcal{O})] \cup [A^c \cap g^{-1}(\mathcal{O})]g−1(O)=[A∩g−1(O)]∪[Ac∩g−1(O)]
is a measurable set, so that ggg is a measurable function.

We continue with more properties of measurable functions.

Theorem 16.4.
If fff and ggg are measurable functions, then the three sets
a. {x∈X:f(x)>g(x)}\{ x \in X : f(x) > g(x) \}{x∈X:f(x)>g(x)},
b. {x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}\{ x \in X : f(x) \geq g(x) \}{x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}, and
c. {x∈X:f(x)=g(x)}\{ x \in X : f(x) = g(x) \}{x∈X:f(x)=g(x)}
are all measurable.

Proof

(a) If r1,r2,…r_1, r_2, \dotsr1​,r2​,… is an enumeration of the rational numbers of R\mathbb{R}R, then
{x∈X:f(x)>g(x)}=⋃n=1∞[{x∈X:f(x)>rn}∩{x∈X:g(x)<rn}],\{ x \in X : f(x) > g(x) \} = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \left[ \{ x \in X : f(x) > r_n \} \cap \{ x \in X : g(x) < r_n \} \right],{x∈X:f(x)>g(x)}=n=1⋃∞​[{x∈X:f(x)>rn​}∩{x∈X:g(x)<rn​}],
which is measurable, since it is a countable union of measurable sets.

(b) Note that
{x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}={x∈X:g(x)>f(x)}c,\{ x \in X : f(x) \geq g(x) \} = \{ x \in X : g(x) > f(x) \}^c,{x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}={x∈X:g(x)>f(x)}c,
which is measurable by (a).

(c) Observe that
{x∈X:f(x)=g(x)}={x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}∩{x∈X:g(x)≥f(x)},\{ x \in X : f(x) = g(x) \} = \{ x \in X : f(x) \geq g(x) \} \cap \{ x \in X : g(x) \geq f(x) \},{x∈X:f(x)=g(x)}={x∈X:f(x)≥g(x)}∩{x∈X:g(x)≥f(x)},
which is measurable by (b).

The next result informs us that the usual algebraic combinations of measurable functions again produce measurable functions.

Theorem 16.5.
For measurable functions fff and ggg, the following statements hold:

  1. f+gf + gf+g is a measurable function.
  2. fgfgfg is a measurable function.
  3. ∣f∣|f|∣f∣, f+f^+f+, and f−f^-f− are measurable functions.
  4. f∨gf \lor gf∨g and f∧gf \land gf∧g are measurable functions.
Proof

(1) Note first that if ccc is a constant number, then c−gc - gc−g is a measurable function.
[Reason: If a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, then
{x∈X:c−g(x)≥a}={x∈X:g(x)≤c−a}\{ x \in X : c - g(x) \geq a \} = \{ x \in X : g(x) \leq c - a \}{x∈X:c−g(x)≥a}={x∈X:g(x)≤c−a}
is a measurable set.]

Now, if a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, then the set
(f+g)−1([a,∞))={x∈X:f(x)+g(x)≥a}={x∈X:f(x)≥a−g(x)}(f + g)^{-1}([a, \infty)) = \{ x \in X : f(x) + g(x) \geq a \} = \{ x \in X : f(x) \geq a - g(x) \}(f+g)−1([a,∞))={x∈X:f(x)+g(x)≥a}={x∈X:f(x)≥a−g(x)}
is measurable by the above observation and Theorem 16.4. Thus, by Theorem 16.2, f+gf + gf+g is a measurable function.

(2) Note first that f2f^2f2 is a measurable function. Indeed, if a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, then we have
{x∈X:f2(x)≤a}=∅if a<0\{ x \in X : f^2(x) \leq a \} = \emptyset \quad \text{if } a < 0{x∈X:f2(x)≤a}=∅if a<0
and
{x∈X:f2(x)≤a}=f−1([−a,a])if a≥0.\{ x \in X : f^2(x) \leq a \} = f^{-1}([-\sqrt{a}, \sqrt{a}]) \quad \text{if } a \geq 0.{x∈X:f2(x)≤a}=f−1([−a​,a​])if a≥0.
Thus, f2f^2f2 is a measurable function by Theorem 16.2. Also, if ccc is a constant number, then cfcfcf is measurable.
[Reason: If A={x∈X:cf(x)≥a}A = \{ x \in X : cf(x) \geq a \}A={x∈X:cf(x)≥a}, then
A={x∈X:f(x)≥a/c}A = \{ x \in X : f(x) \geq a/c \}A={x∈X:f(x)≥a/c} for c>0c > 0c>0 and
A={x∈X:f(x)≤a/c}A = \{ x \in X : f(x) \leq a/c \}A={x∈X:f(x)≤a/c} for c<0c < 0c<0.]

The result now follows from the above observations combined with (1) and the relation
fg=12[(f+g)2−f2−g2].fg = \frac{1}{2}[(f + g)^2 - f^2 - g^2].fg=21​[(f+g)2−f2−g2].

(3) The measurability of ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ follows from the relations
{x∈X:∣f(x)∣≤a}=∅if a<0,\{ x \in X : |f(x)| \leq a \} = \emptyset \quad \text{if } a < 0,{x∈X:∣f(x)∣≤a}=∅if a<0,
and
{x∈X:∣f(x)∣≤a}={x∈X:f(x)≤a}∩{x∈X:f(x)≥−a}if a≥0.\{ x \in X : |f(x)| \leq a \} = \{ x \in X : f(x) \leq a \} \cap \{ x \in X : f(x) \geq -a \} \quad \text{if } a \geq 0.{x∈X:∣f(x)∣≤a}={x∈X:f(x)≤a}∩{x∈X:f(x)≥−a}if a≥0.

For the measurability of f+f^+f+ and f−f^-f−, use the identities
f+=12(∣f∣+f)andf−=12(∣f∣−f).f^+ = \frac{1}{2}(|f| + f) \quad \text{and} \quad f^- = \frac{1}{2}(|f| - f).f+=21​(∣f∣+f)andf−=21​(∣f∣−f).

(4) The identities
f∨g=12(f+g+∣f−g∣)andf∧g=12(f+g−∣f−g∣)f \lor g = \frac{1}{2}(f + g + |f - g|) \quad \text{and} \quad f \land g = \frac{1}{2}(f + g - |f - g|)f∨g=21​(f+g+∣f−g∣)andf∧g=21​(f+g−∣f−g∣)
show that f∨gf \lor gf∨g and f∧gf \land gf∧g are measurable functions.

Theorem 16.6.
For a sequence {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​} of measurable functions, the following statements hold:

  1. If fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e., then fff is a measurable function.

  2. If {fn(x)}\{f_n(x)\}{fn​(x)} is a bounded sequence for each xxx, then lim sup⁡fn\limsup f_nlimsupfn​ and lim inf⁡fn\liminf f_nliminffn​ are both measurable functions.

Proof

(1) Let A={x∈X:lim⁡fn(x)=f(x)}A = \{ x \in X : \lim f_n(x) = f(x) \}A={x∈X:limfn​(x)=f(x)}. Since fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e., it follows that μ∗(Ac)=0\mu^*(A^c) = 0μ∗(Ac)=0. Thus, AcA^cAc is measurable, and hence, AAA is also a measurable set.
Now, let a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R. Observe that the equality
A∩f−1((a,∞))=A∩[⋃n=1∞⋂i=n∞fi−1((a+1n,∞))]A \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty)) = A \cap \left[ \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \bigcap_{i=n}^{\infty} f_i^{-1} \left( \left( a + \frac{1}{n}, \infty \right) \right) \right]A∩f−1((a,∞))=A∩[n=1⋃∞​i=n⋂∞​fi−1​((a+n1​,∞))]
and the measurability of each fif_ifi​ show that A∩f−1((a,∞))A \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty))A∩f−1((a,∞)) is a measurable set.
Also, Ac∩f−1((a,∞))A^c \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty))Ac∩f−1((a,∞)) is a measurable set since it is a subset of a set of measure zero. Thus,
f−1((a,∞))=[A∩f−1((a,∞))]∪[Ac∩f−1((a,∞))]f^{-1}((a, \infty)) = [A \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty))] \cup [A^c \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty))]f−1((a,∞))=[A∩f−1((a,∞))]∪[Ac∩f−1((a,∞))]
is a measurable set. It now easily follows from Theorem 16.2 that fff is a measurable function.

(2) Let {fn(x)}\{ f_n(x) \}{fn​(x)} be bounded for each xxx. We shall show that lim sup⁡fn\limsup f_nlimsupfn​ is a measurable function. The measurability of lim inf⁡fn\liminf f_nliminffn​ will then follow from the identity
lim inf⁡fn=−lim sup⁡(−fn).\liminf f_n = -\limsup(-f_n).liminffn​=−limsup(−fn​).
Note first that
lim sup⁡fn=⋀n=1∞⋁k=n∞fk.\limsup f_n = \bigwedge_{n=1}^{\infty} \bigvee_{k=n}^{\infty} f_k.limsupfn​=n=1⋀∞​k=n⋁∞​fk​.
Fix a natural number nnn. Then the function
hm=fn∨fn+1∨⋯∨fn+mh_m = f_n \vee f_{n+1} \vee \cdots \vee f_{n+m}hm​=fn​∨fn+1​∨⋯∨fn+m​
is measurable for each mmm [by Theorem 16.5(4)], and since hm↑⋁k=n∞fk=gnh_m \uparrow \bigvee_{k=n}^{\infty} f_k = g_nhm​↑⋁k=n∞​fk​=gn​ (everywhere), it follows from part (1) that each gng_ngn​ is a measurable function.
Since gn↓lim sup⁡fng_n \downarrow \limsup f_ngn​↓limsupfn​ (everywhere), by (1) again it follows that lim sup⁡fn\limsup f_nlimsupfn​ is a measurable function, and the proof is complete.

The last two theorems show that the collection of all measurable functions forms a function space containing the limits of its sequences that converge almost everywhere. Moreover, this collection is an algebra under the pointwise product. In other words, the usual operations applied to measurable functions produce measurable functions again.

Therefore, it is natural to ask whether there is a function that fails to be measurable. Clearly, if every subset of XXX is measurable [i.e., Λ=P(X)\Lambda = \mathcal{P}(X)Λ=P(X)], then every real-valued function on XXX is measurable. On the other hand, if there are nonmeasurable sets, then there are also nonmeasurable functions. Indeed, if EEE is a nonmeasurable set, then the function fff defined by
f(x)=1 if x∈Eandf(x)=0 if x∉Ef(x) = 1 \text{ if } x \in E \quad \text{and} \quad f(x) = 0 \text{ if } x \notin Ef(x)=1 if x∈Eandf(x)=0 if x∈/E
is not measurable simply because the set f−1({1})=Ef^{-1}(\{1\}) = Ef−1({1})=E is not measurable.

We close this section with a basic theorem connecting almost everywhere convergence and uniform convergence. The result is due to D. F. Egorov.

Theorem 16.7 (Egorov).
Let {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​} be a sequence of measurable functions such that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f a.e., and let EEE be a measurable subset of XXX such that μ∗(E)<∞\mu^*(E) < \inftyμ∗(E)<∞. Then for every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists a measurable subset FFF of EEE with μ∗(F)<ε\mu^*(F) < \varepsilonμ∗(F)<ε, and with {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​} converging uniformly to fff on E∖FE \setminus FE∖F.

Proof

First note that by removing a null set from XXX, we can assume without loss of generality that lim⁡fn(x)=f(x)\lim f_n(x) = f(x)limfn​(x)=f(x) holds for each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Fix a measurable subset EEE of XXX with μ∗(E)<∞\mu^*(E) < \inftyμ∗(E)<∞. For each pair of positive integers nnn and kkk, let
En,k={x∈E:∣fm(x)−f(x)∣<2−n for all m≥k}.E_{n,k} = \{ x \in E : |f_m(x) - f(x)| < 2^{-n} \text{ for all } m \geq k \}.En,k​={x∈E:∣fm​(x)−f(x)∣<2−n for all m≥k}.
Clearly, each En,kE_{n,k}En,k​ is a measurable subset of XXX. In addition, En,k⊆En,k+1E_{n,k} \subseteq E_{n,k+1}En,k​⊆En,k+1​ holds for all kkk and nnn. Since lim⁡fn(x)=f(x)\lim f_n(x) = f(x)limfn​(x)=f(x) for each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, it easily follows that
En,k↑kEfor each fixed n,E_{n,k} \uparrow_k E \quad \text{for each fixed } n,En,k​↑k​Efor each fixed n,
and so, by Theorem 15.4, we see that
μ∗(En,k)↑kμ∗(E)for each fixed n.\mu^*(E_{n,k}) \uparrow_k \mu^*(E) \quad \text{for each fixed } n.μ∗(En,k​)↑k​μ∗(E)for each fixed n.

Now, let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Since μ∗(E)<∞\mu^*(E) < \inftyμ∗(E)<∞, for each nnn there exists a natural number knk_nkn​ such that
μ∗(E∖En,kn)=μ∗(E)−μ∗(En,kn)<2−nε.\mu^*(E \setminus E_{n,k_n}) = \mu^*(E) - \mu^*(E_{n,k_n}) < 2^{-n} \varepsilon.μ∗(E∖En,kn​​)=μ∗(E)−μ∗(En,kn​​)<2−nε.
Let
F=⋃n=1∞(E∖En,kn).F = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} (E \setminus E_{n,k_n}).F=n=1⋃∞​(E∖En,kn​​).
Then FFF is measurable, F⊆EF \subseteq EF⊆E, and
μ∗(F)≤∑n=1∞μ∗(E∖En,kn)<ε.\mu^*(F) \leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mu^*(E \setminus E_{n,k_n}) < \varepsilon.μ∗(F)≤n=1∑∞​μ∗(E∖En,kn​​)<ε.
Also, if x∈E∖F=⋂n=1∞En,knx \in E \setminus F = \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} E_{n,k_n}x∈E∖F=⋂n=1∞​En,kn​​, then ∣fm(x)−f(x)∣<2−n|f_m(x) - f(x)| < 2^{-n}∣fm​(x)−f(x)∣<2−n holds for each m≥knm \geq k_nm≥kn​. This shows that {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​} converges uniformly to fff on E∖FE \setminus FE∖F, and the proof of the theorem is complete.
